<!DOCTYPE HTML PUBLIC "-//IETF//DTD HTML//EN">

<html>

<head>
<title>Untitled</title>
<meta name="GENERATOR" content="Microsoft FrontPage 1.1">
</head>

<body bgcolor="#FFFFFF">
<p><font size=5><b><img src="gif/mhirsl.gif" align=bottom width=312 height=62> <img src="gif/mhiweb.gif" align=bottom width=312 height=62></b></font></p>
<p><font size=6><b>Workspace &#174; utilised in development of new robot:</b></font></p>
<p><font size=5><b>Mitsubishi PA-10 and controller language offered with Workspace &#174;</b></font><b> 
</b><font size=5><b>release 4.0.</b></font></p>
<p><font size=4><b>Joint development efforts result in new 7 axis robot for highly complex applications. Robot 
Simulations offers modelling and off-line programming as standard option in Workspace &#174;. <br>
</b></font></p>
<p><b>Newcastle upon Tyne, UK. Robot Simulations Ltd., has announced the successful completion of a unique joint 
development effort between Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, RSL and the RSL Sales and Marketing dealers in 
Japan, Robotmation and the Marubeni Hitech. This has lead to the launch of the new PA-10 robot as standard 
within Workspace &#174; 4.0 for Windows &#174; 95. </b></p>
<p><b><br>
This robot has 7 axes, is lightweight, and is designed to perform many applications outside of the range or scope of 
traditional industrial robots. This is based on the improved degree of freedom and general useability. Industrial 
robots currently on market have five or six degrees of freedom. However in order to deal with the increasingly 
complex robot work, such as obstacle avoidance, confined space access etc. MHI have provided the solution by 
designing seven degrees of freedom (RPRPRPR R = Rotation, P = Pivot)<br>
</b><a href="pa-10.wrl"><img src="gif/pa-10.gif" align=bottom border=0 width=300 height=298></a> </p>
<p><b>After the technical development team at RSL had completed the kinematic modelling of this new robot in close 
co-operation with MHI, the controller language was developed. Much thought was put into the usability to 
maximise the off-line programming features of Workspace. With the future complexity of the tasks that the PA-10 
will be utilised, off-line programming and simulation for cell layout will be an important element in the functionality 
of the robot. <br>
</b></p>
<p><i>&quot;We are happy to work with any robot manufacturer in the world to bring this type of joint technological innovation 
to the robotics industry&quot;, </i><b>says Roger Verrall, Managing Director of RSL.</b><i> &quot;By bringing together the expertise of 
RSL and robot manufacturers we can help to move the industry to the higher levels that they seek&quot;.<br>
</i></p>
<p><b>For more information on WORKSPACE &#174; and Robotrak &#174; contact RSL as follows:-</b></p>
<p><b>Internet:</b><a href="index.htm"><b> http://www.rosl.com</b></a> </p>
<p><b>e.mail:</b><a href="MAILTO:roger@rosl.demon.co.uk"><b> roger@rosl.demon.co.uk</b></a></p>
<p><b>Fax: +44 (0) 191 272 0121</b> </p>
<p><b>Telephone: +44 (0) 191 272 3673.<br>
</b></p>
<p><b>For more information on the PA-10 robot or MHI please contact them direct on:-</b></p>
<p><b>Internet:</b><a href="http://www1.meshnet.or.jp/kobe-mic/mhikobe/products"><b> http://www1.meshnet.or.jp/kobe-mic/mhikobe/products</b></a></p>
<p><b>Fax: 00-813-3212-9859</b> </p>
<p><b>Telephone: 00-813-3212-3111</b> </p>
<p align=center><img src="gif/line_col.gif" align=bottom width=585 height=1></p>
<h6 align=center><font color="#000000"><b>Workspace</b> and <b>Robotrak</b> are registered trademarks of Robot Simulations Ltd. </font></h6>
<h6 align=center><font color="#000000">UK Patent Application Number 952006.4 </font></h6>
<h6 align=center><font color="#000000">US Patent Application Number 952006.4 (Applied for) </font></h6>
<h6 align=center><font color="#000000">Copyright &#169; 1996 Robot Simulations Ltd</font></h6>

<TITLE>Some <B>Workspace</B> workcells presented as virtual worlds</TITLE>

<BODY background="paper3.gif">

<H1>Some <B>Workspace</B> workcells presented as virtual worlds</H1> 

Workspace models may be saved as virtual worlds that may be viewed using a VRML compatible web-browser. Links to some examples are shown below. If your browser does not recognise the file type then <A HREF="vrmlbrow.htm">upgrade your browser to recognise VRML</A>.

<center><IMG SRC="line_col.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></img></center>

<UL>
<LI><A HREF="fzanlage.wrz">An ABB IRB2000 and an Adept One picking and placing parts on a conveyor</A> (48k bytes)


</UL>

<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Workspace technical specifications</TITLE> 
<BODY background="paper3.gif">
<H1>Workspace technical specifications</H1> 
</HEAD>

<H3>Workspace 3+ robot simulation software</H3>
<UL>
<IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></img>Kinematic modeller
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">Discrete event simulation
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">Interactive creation of new mechanisms
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"><A HREF="rtrkspec.htm">In-built robot and fixture calibration system</A>   
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"><A HREF="robmods.htm">Library of standard robots</A>              
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"><A HREF="language.htm">Robot languages</A>
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">Ability to easily offline programme applications using Workspace geometry point paths
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">Applications including spot welding, arc welding, paint spraying, material handling, sealant, laser cutting, water jet and deburring
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">Tool graphics designed to simulate tool action
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">Statistical analysis of Robot Workcells 
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">Dynamics simulator
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">Forces and torques calculated
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">Graphical representation of results 
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">Text editor
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">Accurate representation of mechanisms
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">Calculation of cycle times
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">Teachpoint files 
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">Collision detection
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"><A HREF="scrshots.htm">Example robots and workcells</A> 
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">Simple authoring of training exercises      <br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">Computer Aided Learning
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">Tutorial exercises 
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">User Manuals
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"><A HREF="telemani.htm">Telemanipulation option</A>

</UL>
<center><IMG SRC="line_col.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></img></center>            
<H3>Integrated CAD system</H3>
<UL>

</UL>

<DOCHDR>
http://www.rosl.com:80/sport.htm 206.216.148.51 19970121063730 text/html 4125
HTTP/1.0 200 OK

<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>SPORT</TITLE> 
</HEAD>
<BODY background="paper3.gif">
<H1>SPORT</H1> 

<h2>Introduction</h2>

<P><B>SPORT</B> is a text-based offline software package which makes it possible to write ABB robot programs in the language Arla on an external personal computer and then download them to an S3 robot controller. It is fully compatible with Arla programmes created by Workspace and may be used as an alternative to using ABB software to download these text files to an S3 controller.</p> 

<P>The latest release of <B>SPORT</B> has the following capabilities:</P>
<UL>
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></img>
File compilation - Convert a robot program from ARLA to binary code.
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">Task compilation - Convert all robot programs in a task from ARLA to binary code.
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">Diskette Functions -  Using diskette to transfer program between robot and PC.
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">On Line Communication - Communication between robot and PC via serial link.
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">File decompilation - Convert a robot program from binary code to ARLA robot language.
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">Block decompilation - Convert a block of robot programs from binary code to ARLA.
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">Program Editor - Creating robot programs and transfer position and orientation data via DDE to SPORT from AutoCAD.
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">OLP-import - A file with .irb extension created in OLP3 (english or swedish) can be converted to SPORT standard.
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">Printing - Print a file: File, Print, (notepad starts with the actual file), you may add comments to the file, Arkiv, Skriv ut.
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">Possible to specify a Word processor (WinWord, Write, Notepad...). The word processor is started from the menu or by Ctrl+Enter in a .rpl-file or a selected .rpl-file in the task-file.
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">If a file excedes 64kb the specified word processor will be started automatically.
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">As a complement to task a new feature with block files (extension .IRB) has been introduced which is compatible with olp irb files.
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">This version of SPORT has debugging capabilities. This application shows the current running line in the task by highlighting it. 
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">Prodebug.exe has DDE (Dynamic Data Exchange) to the to sailserv.exe, a module for robot control. 
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">This version is shipped with the ADS aplication SAIL (Simulation AId for Link mechanisms). This is a general module for kinematic simulation in AutoCAD for Windows. Via DDE are the module SAILSERV and SAIL communicating and the model of the ABB2000 are automatically updated during the simulation.
</UL>

<h2>New Features in the latest release</h2>

<P>Release 1.51 adds new features to the SPORT system.</P>

<UL>
<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">TCP calibration -  You are now able to measure the TCP and Basepoint of the robot and directlly update the
TCP register of the controller.

<br><IMG SRC="ball_red.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]">External axes are now supported both in the editor and in the communication part
</UL>
<center><IMG SRC="line_col.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></img></center>


<P ALIGN=center><A HREF="index.htm"><IMG SRC="home.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></a>[ <A HREF="index.htm">Return to Home Page</A> ]</P> 

<center><IMG SRC="line_col.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></img></center>

<h6>Copyright &copy; 1996 Robot Simulations Ltd</h6>
<h6>Last revision 3 April 1996</h6></center>
</P>

<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>Robotrak/Workspace robot calibration features and technical specifications</TITLE> 
<BODY background="paper3.gif">
<H1>Robotrak/Workspace robot calibration features and technical specifications</H1> 
</HEAD>
<center><IMG SRC="rtrk1.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></center>

<H2>How Robotrak works</H2>

<P>Robotrak is a 3d measuring device used for calibrating robots. Three cords extend from drums fixed in the cell in a triangle arrangement to meet at the end of the robot. The extensions of each cord is measured by optical encoder on the drum which report the rotation of the drum. Given the lengths of the three cords and the distances between the drums which is discovered during the self-calibration setup for Robotrak it is possible to calculate the true position of the endpoint of the robot.</P>
<P>The software for setting up and using Robotrak is embedded in Workspace and compares measurements taken using Robotrak to the teachpoints for the same positions recorded by the robot. Workspace then extracts the errors in the nominal controller model of the robot to produce a filter which sits between the simulation and the robot and fools the inaccurate robot into achieving going accurately to the desired position.</P>

<H2>Parameters calibrated for</H2>

<UL>
<LI>Joint zero positions
<LI>Link lengths
<LI>Misalignment of successive joints
<LI>Tool offset
<LI>Position and orientation of the measuring system (Robotrak)
<LI>Joint compliance due to weight of payload and links
</UL>

<H2>Other technical data</H2>
<UL>
<LI>Repeatability of Robotrak - 0.3mm
<LI>Kinematic model used - 5 parameter DH model
<LI>Repeatability of uncalibrated Robot - typically 0.1mm
<LI>Accuracy of uncalibrated robot - between 15mm and 2mm
<LI>Accuracy of calibrated robot - 1mm
<LI>Overall time taken for setup and robot calibration - 30 to 60 minutes
</UL>
<center><IMG SRC="line_col.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></img></center>

<P ALIGN=center> <A HREF="calib.htm">Calibration using Workspace and Robotrak in more detail</A> </P> 
<center><IMG SRC="line_col.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></img></center>


<P ALIGN=center><A HREF="index.htm"><IMG SRC="home.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></a>[ <A HREF="index.htm">Return to Home Page</A> ]</P> 

<center><IMG SRC="line_col.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></img></center>


<center><h6><b>Workspace</b> and <b>Robotrak</b> are registered trademarks of Robot Simulations Ltd.</h6>

<h6>Copyright &copy; 1996 Robot Simulations Ltd</h6>
<h6>Last revision 3 April 1996</h6></center>
</P>

<DOCHDR>
http://www.rosl.com:80/wwwboard/faq.html 206.216.148.51 19970121064112 text/html 2180
HTTP/1.0 200 OK
Date: Tue, 21 Jan 1997 06:37:30 GMT
Server: Apache/1.0.2
Content-type: text/html
Content-length: 2009
Last-modified: Thu, 23 May 1996 14:32:59 GMT
</DOCHDR>
<html><head><title>Robot Simulations Frequently Asked Questions</title></head>
<body><h1>Robot Simulations Frequently Asked Questions and Answers</h1>
Here is a brief explanation of some of the questions you may have 
about WWWBoard.<hr>
<ul>
<li><a href="#links">Can I use html tags anywhere in my posts?</a>
<li><a href="#colons">Why are there colons in the message section when I 
try post a followup?</a>
<li><a href="#reload">Why didn't my post show up?</a>
<li><a href="#getit">Where can I get the scripts for this program?</a>
</ul><hr><p>
<a name="links">Can I put html tags anywhere in my posts?</a><p>
No.  You can not use HTML tags in any field except body of the message.  
The maintainer of the script has the option of allowing or 
disallowing any HTML in the Message part of your posting.  If 
they disallow it, the script will just throw out everything in 
&lt;&gt;'s.  If they allow it, your html markup will appear in 
the posting.  It can't hurt to try.<p><hr><p> 

<a name="colons">Why are there colons in the message when I try to post a 
followup?</a><p>
Colons appear in the message dialog box when you try to followup up on a 
message to indicate that those lines are quoting the previous document. 
The owner of the WWWBoard can decide whether they wish to enable or 
disable the quoting of previous messages.<p><hr><p>


<a name="reload">Why didn't my post show up?</a><p>
Your post most likely did not show up, because your browser did not reload the 
page, it simply pulled it out of cache.  Please reload your browser and it 
should then appear.<p><hr><p>
<a name="getit">Where can I get the scripts for this program?</a><p>
The scripts are written in Perl and created by <a 
href="http://alpha.pr1.k12.co.us/~mattw/home.html">Matt Wright</a>.  They are 
free to anyone who wishes to use them and you can get them as well as other 
scripts at: <a href="http://worldwidemart.com/scripts/">http://worldwidemart.com/scripts/</a>.  
Enjoy!<p><hr>
</DOC>
<DOC>

      <h1>planar stewart platform</h1>
    </center>
<hr size=7 width=75%>
<center>[ <a href="#followups">Follow Ups</a> ] [ <a href="#postfp">Post Followup</a> ] [ <a href="http://www.rosl.com/wwwboard/wwwboard.html">Workspace User Group</a> ] [ <a href="http://www.rosl.com/wwwboard/faq.html">FAQ</a> ]</center>

: I received an error message of&quot;no name&quot; after I had sent my message yesterday.

: I wanted to know whether the inverse kinematics of a stewart platform with rotary drive  is straightforward as that with prismatic legs !!

: I mean , replacing the prismatic legs with crank and coupler mechanism.

: waiting for a comment on this 

: Thank you.

:                                                Huxley..


</textarea>

Posted by <a href="mailto:A.Beck1@plymouth.ac.uk">Alexander Beck</a> on November 22, 1996 at 09:39:07:<p>
Dear Sirs.<p>I am a student of Robotics and Automated Systems. I use workspace in my final year project.<br>To control an UMI RTX100 robot within the 'usermove.dll' it is necessary to know the joint<br>angles of the robot.  The interface of the 'ExtUserMove' procedure supplies position data of<br>type xyzwpr. Therefore I would like to ask if it is possible to get the joint angle data into the<br>'usermove.dll, or if it is possible to access the inverse kinematics procedure used in<br>workspace.<p>Thank you for your time. I look forward to hearing from you soon.<p>Best regards,<p>Alexander Beck	<br>
<br>

<html>
  <head>
    <title>Which is the most advanced off-line language?</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <center>
      <h1>Which is the most advanced off-line language?</h1>
    </center>
<hr size=7 width=75%>
<center>[ <a href="#followups">Follow Ups</a> ] [ <a href="#postfp">Post Followup</a> ] [ <a href="http://www.rosl.com/wwwboard/wwwboard.html">Workspace User Group</a> ] [ <a href="http://www.rosl.com/wwwboard/faq.html">FAQ</a> ]</center>
<hr size=7 width=75%><p>
Posted by <a href="mailto:gtkim@salmosa.kaist.ac.kr">Gyutae Kim</a> on October 24, 1996 at 01:10:07:<p>
Hello!<br> I am currently desinging a new off-line robot language<br>in which most of the needed features are included.<br>AutoTask, the one I am talking about, includes ;<br>   1. Task-level instructions<br>   2. Object-orientation with inheritence<br>   3. Concurrent mechanism with message passing<br>   4. Exception handling<br>   5. New data types for geometric data<br>   etc.<br>This language looks like C++.<br>I added a Task[GT] concept to make it possible of<br>task-level programming.  This concept is similar to<br>Ada's task, but not that one!<p>Comments are welcomed.<p>Would like to connect with WS3 by means of using<br>existing most advanced language which has above<br>similar features(conversion!).<br>But I don't know which is best and have problems of<br>using the demo version at the moment, since it has<br>very many limitations.(almost imposible!)<p>Is there no way? ...<p>PS) How can I get the language reference manual,<br>    via WEB or FTP, of Karel3 or another most<br>    advanced lanugage you may suggest?<br>
<br>
<br><hr size=7 width=75%><p>
<a name="followups">Follow Ups:</a><br>
<ul><!--insert: 74-->
<!--top: 93--><li><a href="93.html">Re: Which is the most advanced off-line language?</a> <b>Xing Shusong</b> <i>04:19:57 12/16/96</i>
(<!--responses: 93-->0)
<ul><!--insert: 93-->
</ul><!--end: 93-->
</ul><!--end: 74-->
<br><hr size=7 width=75%><p>
<a name="postfp">Post a Followup</a><p>
<form method=POST action="http://www.rosl.com/my-cgi-bin/wwwboard.cgi">
<input type=hidden name="followup" value="74">
<input type=hidden name="origname" value="Gyutae Kim">
<input type=hidden name="origemail" value="gtkim@salmosa.kaist.ac.kr">
<input type=hidden name="origsubject" value="Which is the most advanced off-line language?">
<input type=hidden name="origdate" value="October 24, 1996 at 01:10:07">
Name: <input type=text name="name" size=50><br>
E-Mail: <input type=text name="email" size=50><p>
Subject: <input type=text name="subject" value="Re: Which is the most advanced off-line language?" size=50><p>
Comments:<br>
<textarea name="body" COLS=50 ROWS=10>
: Hello!
:  I am currently desinging a new off-line robot language
: in which most of the needed features are included.
: AutoTask, the one I am talking about, includes ;
:    1. Task-level instructions
:    2. Object-orientation with inheritence
:    3. Concurrent mechanism with message passing
:    4. Exception handling
:    5. New data types for geometric data
:    etc.
: This language looks like C++.
: I added a Task[GT] concept to make it possible of
: task-level programming.  This concept is similar to
: Ada's task, but not that one!

: Comments are welcomed.

: Would like to connect with WS3 by means of using
: existing most advanced language which has above
: similar features(conversion!).
: But I don't know which is best and have problems of
: using the demo version at the moment, since it has
: very many limitations.(almost imposible!)

: Is there no way? ...

: PS) How can I get the language reference manual,
:     via WEB or FTP, of Karel3 or another most
:     advanced lanugage you may suggest?

</textarea>

Hi! your work is very interesting, I think you may try Java, it's high level from hardware is very suitable for task planning. Of course, you will have many works on programming various interface and driver programs. Many class lib that you will need have not appeared.<br>: Hello!<br>:  I am currently desinging a new off-line robot language<br>: in which most of the needed features are included.<br>: AutoTask, the one I am talking about, includes ;<br>:    1. Task-level instructions<br>:    2. Object-orientation with inheritence<br>:    3. Concurrent mechanism with message passing<br>:    4. Exception handling<br>:    5. New data types for geometric data<br>:    etc.<br>: This language looks like C++.<br>: I added a Task[GT] concept to make it possible of<br>: task-level programming. E-Mail: <input type=text name="email" size=50><p>
Subject: <input type=text name="subject"value="Re: Which is the most advanced off-line language?" size=50><p>
Comments:<br>
<textarea name="body" COLS=50 ROWS=10>
: Hi! your work is very interesting, I think you may try Java, it's high level from hardware is very suitable for task planning. Of course, you will have many works on programming various interface and driver programs. Many class lib that you will need have not appeared.
: : Hello!
: :  I am currently desinging a new off-line robot language
: : in which most of the needed features are included.
: : AutoTask, the one I am talking about, includes ;
: :    1. Task-level instructions
: :    2. Object-orientation with inheritence
: :    3. Concurrent mechanism with message passing
: :    4. Exception handling
: :    5. New data types for geometric data
: :    etc.
: : This language looks like C++.
: : I added a Task[GT] concept to make it possible of
: : task-level programming.  This concept is similar to
: : Ada's task, but not that one!

: : Comments are welcomed.

: : Would like to connect with WS3 by means of using
: : existing most advanced language which has above
: : similar features(conversion!).
: : But I don't know which is best and have problems of
: : using the demo version at the moment, since it has
: : very many limitations.(almost imposible!)

: : Is there no way? ...

: : PS) How can I get the language reference manual,
: :     via WEB or FTP, of Karel3 or another most
: :     advanced lanugage you may suggest?

</textarea>
<p>
Optional Link URL: <input type=text name="url" size=50><br>
Link Title: <input type=text name="url_title" size=48><br>
Optional Image URL: <input type=text name="img" size=49><p>

  </head>
  <body>
    <center>
      <h1>External I/O for Bosch SR800 Robots</h1>
    </center>
<hr size=7 width=75%>
<center>[ <a href="#followups">Follow Ups</a> ] [ <a href="#postfp">Post Followup</a> ] [ <a href="http://www.rosl.com/wwwboard/wwwboard.html">Workspace User Group</a> ] [ <a href="http://www.rosl.com/wwwboard/faq.html">FAQ</a> ]</center>
<hr size=7 width=75%><p>
Posted by <a href="mailto:acrosse@rtc-waterford.ie">Alec Crosse</a> on September 27, 1996 at 07:33:11:<p>
I work with 2 Bosch SR800 robots  (scara) utilising <br>a Rho 2 control and need some help in connecting up <br>external inputs & outputs .<br>I also need help on how to define these I/O in the <br>BAPS program  and how to use them within,a sample<br>program would be of great help.<p>Here is a basic program I tried:<p>1  PROGRAM AAAA<br>2  INPUT:50=SENSOR<br>3  OUTPUT:10=SOLINOID<br>4  WAITUNTIL SENSOR=1<br>5  MOVE TO POINT_1<br>6  SOLENOID=1<br>7  MOVE TO POINT_2<br>8  END<p>Program compiles fine with no errors  but will not run<br>when sensor is on .If I remove the mention of sensor &<br>input (lines 2,4), the program runs but the solenoid is<br>turned on, not between the move between pt1 to pt2 but <br>at the end of the program.
<br>
<br><hr size=7 width=75%><p>

: BAPS program  and how to use them within,a sample

: 7  MOVE TO POINT_2
: 8  END

: when sensor is on .If I remove the mention of sensor &
: input (lines 2,4), the program runs but the solenoid is
: turned on, not between the move between pt1 to pt2 but 
: at the end of the program.

<DOCHDR>
http://www.rosl.com:80/wwwboard/messages/57.html 206.216.148.51 19970121064838 text/html 2976
HTTP/1.0 200 OK
Date: Tue, 21 Jan 1997 06:45:02 GMT

<html>
  <head>
    <title>Re: Convert MOD to VRML format </title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <center>
      <h1>Re: Convert MOD to VRML format </h1>
    </center>
<hr size=7 width=75%>
<center>[ <a href="#followups">Follow Ups</a> ] [ <a href="#postfp">Post Followup</a> ] [ <a href="http://www.rosl.com/wwwboard/wwwboard.html">Workspace User Group</a> ] [ <a href="http://www.rosl.com/wwwboard/faq.html">FAQ</a> ]</center>
<hr size=7 width=75%><p>
Posted by <a href="mailto:marc@rosl.demon.couk">Marc Burns</a> on September 05, 1996 at 07:32:00:<p>
In Reply to: <a href="54.html">Convert MOD to VRML format </a> posted by Blaz Dolinsek on September 04, 1996 at 01:17:12:<p>
<br>Workspace 4 ( our next release ) allows the  user not only save models as VRML but also<br>create moving VRML's of animations created within Workspace. The examples of static <br>and dynamic VRML's on our website were created within Workspace.<p>Also, all models created within older versions of Workspace are compatible so you will not <br>have to create new model from scratch. 
<br>
<br><hr size=7 width=75%><p>
<a name="followups">Follow Ups:</a><br>

<input type=hidden name="followup" value="54,57">
<input type=hidden name="origname" value="Marc Burns">
<input type=hidden name="origemail" value="marc@rosl.demon.couk">
<input type=hidden name="origsubject" value="Re: Convert MOD to VRML format ">
<input type=hidden name="origdate" value="September 05, 1996 at 07:32:00">
Name: <input type=text name="name" size=50><br>
E-Mail: <input type=text name="email" size=50><p>
Subject: <input type=text name="subject"value="Re: Convert MOD to VRML format " size=50><p>
Comments:<br>
<textarea name="body" COLS=50 ROWS=10>
: 
: Workspace 4 ( our next release ) allows the  user not only save models as VRML but also
: create moving VRML's of animations created within Workspace. The examples of static 
: and dynamic VRML's on our website were created within Workspace.

: Also, all models created within older versions of Workspace are compatible so you will not 
: have to create new model from scratch. 

</textarea>

    <title>problem with cprogram interface with robot</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <center>
      <h1>problem with cprogram interface with robot</h1>
    </center>
<hr size=7 width=75%>
<center>[ <a href="#followups">Follow Ups</a> ] [ <a href="#postfp">Post Followup</a> ] [ <a href="http://www.rosl.com/wwwboard/wwwboard.html">Workspace User Group</a> ] [ <a href="http://www.rosl.com/wwwboard/faq.html">FAQ</a> ]</center>
<hr size=7 width=75%><p>
Posted by <a href="mailto:taykw@pacific.net.sg">Taykw</a> on August 15, 1996 at 08:04:11:<p>
Our company owns a Mitsubishi industrial micro-robot<br>model RV-M2. I have encountered problem of c program <br>interface with the robot via RS 232 serial port. the C<br>function format used to send to the robot is <br>  fputs("string of robot commands",stdaux); but always<br>received no respond from the robot, can anyone up in <br>the cyber space tell me why? Thanks, regards.<br> 
<br>

<html>
  <head>
    <title>Re: problem with cprogram interface with robot</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <center>
      <h1>Re: problem with cprogram interface with robot</h1>
    </center>
<hr size=7 width=75%>
<center>[ <a href="#followups">Follow Ups</a> ] [ <a href="#postfp">Post Followup</a> ] [ <a href="http://www.rosl.com/wwwboard/wwwboard.html">Workspace User Group</a> ] [ <a href="http://www.rosl.com/wwwboard/faq.html">FAQ</a> ]</center>
<hr size=7 width=75%><p>
Posted by <a href="mailto:nick@rosl.demon.co.uk">Nick Oakley</a> on August 22, 1996 at 09:03:03:<p>
In Reply to: <a href="47.html">problem with cprogram interface with robot</a> posted by Taykw on August 15, 1996 at 08:04:11:<p>
Dear Mr. Tay Khee Wee,<br>I have sent you an email concerning the above and<br>look forward to your response. I suggest that you<br>poll the com port for a change in the state of its<br>flags before attempting to transmit the next<br>command. This is because the controller is busy<br>and loses the first few characters of the next<br>command, thus causing a syntax error when it <br>eventually starts to take notice of its serial<br>port again.<br>Alternatively, you could configure the port for<br>an infinite number of retries from DOS but I am<br>not certain if this will affect the operation of<br>your .exe file.<p>Regards,<p>Nick Oakley for Robot Simulations Ltd.
<br>
<br><hr size=7 width=75%><p>
<a name="followups">Follow Ups:</a><br>
<ul><!--insert: 53-->
</ul><!--end: 53-->
<br><hr size=7 width=75%><p>
<a name="postfp">Post a Followup</a><p>
<form method=POST action="http://www.rosl.com/my-cgi-bin/wwwboard.cgi">
<input type=hidden name="followup" value="47,53">
<input type=hidden name="origname" value="Nick Oakley">
<input type=hidden name="origemail" value="nick@rosl.demon.co.uk">
<input type=hidden name="origsubject" value="Re: problem with cprogram interface with robot">
<input type=hidden name="origdate" value="August 22, 1996 at 09:03:03">
Name: <input type=text name="name" size=50><br>
E-Mail: <input type=text name="email" size=50><p>
Subject: <input type=text name="subject"value="Re: problem with cprogram interface with robot" size=50><p>
Comments:<br>
<textarea name="body" COLS=50 ROWS=10>
: Dear Mr. Tay Khee Wee,
: I have sent you an email concerning the above and
: look forward to your response. I suggest that you
: poll the com port for a change in the state of its
: flags before attempting to transmit the next
: command. This is because the controller is busy
: and loses the first few characters of the next
: command, thus causing a syntax error when it 
: eventually starts to take notice of its serial
: port again.
: Alternatively, you could configure the port for
: an infinite number of retries from DOS but I am
: not certain if this will affect the operation of
: your .exe file.

: Regards,

: Nick Oakley for Robot Simulations Ltd.

</textarea>

<html>
  <head>
    <title>Re: robot languages</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <center>
      <h1>Re: robot languages</h1>
    </center>
<hr size=7 width=75%>
<center>[ <a href="#followups">Follow Ups</a> ] [ <a href="#postfp">Post Followup</a> ] [ <a href="http://www.rosl.com/wwwboard/wwwboard.html">Workspace User Group</a> ] [ <a href="http://www.rosl.com/wwwboard/faq.html">FAQ</a> ]</center>
<hr size=7 width=75%><p>
Posted by <a href="mailto:ENTROPY34@GNN.COM">Woody Walker</a> on September 22, 1996 at 21:56:27:<p>
In Reply to: <a href="42.html">robot languages</a> posted by Tiberio Grasso on August 01, 1996 at 06:53:13:<p>
I am a programming technician for Collins & Aikman and we currently have about thirty eight "Yasnac Motoman" robots in a waterjet based application. The information we have regarding actual offline programming and the INFORM language itself is very sparse. I really need some source code for this language to better understand it's opperation and to help us tailor the application to our needs. Any takers on this one?<br>Also,  I really need some conversion algorithoms for conversion so i can convert from standard job to relative job and vice versa. PLEASE HELP... im stupid!<br>
<br>
<br><hr size=7 width=75%><p>
<a name="followups">Follow Ups:</a><br>
<ul><!--insert: 59-->
<!--top: 61--><li><a href="61.html">Re: robot languages</a> <b>Walt Weisel</b> <i>02:55:50 9/25/96</i>
(<!--responses: 61-->0)

<!--top: 60--><li><a href="60.html">Re: robot languages</a> <b>Woody Walker</b> <i>22:02:53 9/22/96</i>

<html>
  <head>
    <title>Re: Animation of ABB Robot</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <center>
      <h1>Re: Animation of ABB Robot</h1>
    </center>
<hr size=7 width=75%>
<center>[ <a href="#followups">Follow Ups</a> ] [ <a href="#postfp">Post Followup</a> ] [ <a href="http://www.rosl.com/wwwboard/wwwboard.html">Workspace User Group</a> ] [ <a href="http://www.rosl.com/wwwboard/faq.html">FAQ</a> ]</center>
<hr size=7 width=75%><p>
Posted by <a href="mailto:john@rosl.demon.co.uk">John Owens</a> on July 17, 1996 at 08:38:11:<p>
In Reply to: <a href="37.html">Animation of ABB Robot</a> posted by Diana Casetti (FANUC Robotics) on July 17, 1996 at 08:27:16:<p>
I'm afraid the format is complex and undocumented by Netscape, apart<br>from the geometry stuff which is standard VRML 1.0 (use a search enigine<br>for more info on VRML). If you use GZip to unzip into WRL and VUE files<br>then you can see the text files. Its the VUE file that make stuff move<br>and which Netscape seem to deny the existence of, even though it does<br>work in their browser.<p>We have a command built into Workspace that generates these files. If<br>you want we might be able to generate a Fanuc one for you but I'd need<br>to know a little bit more about what you intended doing with it (I guess<br>we'd be looking for a bit of free publicity). We have all the Fanuc<br>robots modelled on Workspace.<br>
<br>
<br><hr size=7 width=75%><p>

http://www.rosl.com:80/wwwboard/messages/39.html 206.216.148.51 19970121065310 text/html 2821
HTTP/1.0 200 OK
Date: Tue, 21 Jan 1997 06:49:32 GMT

</DOCHDR>
<html>
  <head>
    <title>Re: WS3 cycle times</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <center>
      <h1>Re: WS3 cycle times</h1>
    </center>
<hr size=7 width=75%>
<center>[ <a href="#followups">Follow Ups</a> ] [ <a href="#postfp">Post Followup</a> ] [ <a href="http://www.rosl.com/wwwboard/wwwboard.html">Workspace User Group</a> ] [ <a href="http://www.rosl.com/wwwboard/faq.html">FAQ</a> ]</center>
<hr size=7 width=75%><p>
Posted by <a href="mailto:james@rosl.demon.co.uk">James Potter</a> on July 19, 1996 at 06:07:46:<p>
In Reply to: <a href="35.html">WS3</a> posted by Jeffrey Moore on July 09, 1996 at 17:54:31:<p>
We have compared cycle times predicted in <br>Workspace against those measured on real robots,<br>and found the predicted times to be approximately<br>95% accurate.<p>Workspace robot models contain information on <br>joint/tool maximum speed/acceleration and <br>Workspace uses trajectory generation algorithms <br>supplied by robot manufacturers.
<br>
<br><hr size=7 width=75%><p>
<a name="followups">Follow Ups:</a><br>
<ul><!--insert: 39-->
</ul><!--end: 39-->
<br><hr size=7 width=75%><p>
<a name="postfp">Post a Followup</a><p>
<form method=POST action="http://www.rosl.com/my-cgi-bin/wwwboard.cgi">
<input type=hidden name="followup" value="35,39">
<input type=hidden name="origname" value="James Potter">
<input type=hidden name="origemail" value="james@rosl.demon.co.uk">
<input type=hidden name="origsubject" value="Re: WS3 cycle times">
<input type=hidden name="origdate" value="July 19, 1996 at 06:07:46">
Name: <input type=text name="name" size=50><br>
E-Mail: <input type=text name="email" size=50><p>
Subject: <input type=text name="subject"value="Re: WS3 cycle times" size=50><p>
Comments:<br>
<textarea name="body" COLS=50 ROWS=10>
: We have compared cycle times predicted in 
: Workspace against those measured on real robots,
: and found the predicted times to be approximately
: 95% accurate.

: Workspace robot models contain information on 
: joint/tool maximum speed/acceleration and 
: Workspace uses trajectory generation algorithms 
: supplied by robot manufacturers.

</textarea>
<p>

<html>
  <head>
    <title>Re: Stewart Platform</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <center>
      <h1>Re: Stewart Platform</h1>
    </center>
<hr size=7 width=75%>
<center>[ <a href="#followups">Follow Ups</a> ] [ <a href="#postfp">Post Followup</a> ] [ <a href="http://www.rosl.com/wwwboard/wwwboard.html">Workspace User Group</a> ] [ <a href="http://www.rosl.com/wwwboard/faq.html">FAQ</a> ]</center>
<hr size=7 width=75%><p>
Posted by <a href="mailto:phil@rosl.demon.co.uk">Phil Watson</a> on June 13, 1996 at 08:54:00:<p>
In Reply to: <a href="29.html">Stewart Platform</a> posted by Tony Vidler on June 08, 1996 at 18:01:23:<p>
: One of our contacts has posed the question as to<br>: whether it is possible to create and simulate a Stewart<br>: Platform using Workspace.<p>Workspace can be used to simulate both serial and<br>tree type mechanisms. They are defined by modelling<br>the joints that make up the mechanism.<p>Each joint can be either rotational or translational,<br>each joint is defined between its parent object and <br>its child object, and its motion is governed by <br>user defined equations. These equations consist of <br>any number of temporary variable definitions and <br>a final definition line. This structure allow <br>complex equations to be modelled easily.<p>This method of mechanism modelling allows Workspace to simulate<br>any mechanism type including the Stewart Platform and the Neos <br>Tricept robot.<p><br>The <p><br>
<br>
<br><hr size=7 width=75%><p>
<a name="followups">Follow Ups:</a><br>

<a name="postfp">Post a Followup</a><p>
<form method=POST action="http://www.rosl.com/my-cgi-bin/wwwboard.cgi">
<input type=hidden name="followup" value="29,32">
<input type=hidden name="origname" value="Phil Watson">
<input type=hidden name="origemail" value="phil@rosl.demon.co.uk">
<input type=hidden name="origsubject" value="Re: Stewart Platform">
<input type=hidden name="origdate" value="June 13, 1996 at 08:54:00">
Name: <input type=text name="name" size=50><br>
E-Mail: <input type=text name="email" size=50><p>
Subject: <input type=text name="subject"value="Re: Stewart Platform" size=50><p>
Comments:<br>
<textarea name="body" COLS=50 ROWS=10>
: : One of our contacts has posed the question as to
: : whether it is possible to create and simulate a Stewart
: : Platform using Workspace.

: Workspace can be used to simulate both serial and
: tree type mechanisms. They are defined by modelling
: the joints that make up the mechanism.

: Each joint can be either rotational or translational,
: each joint is defined between its parent object and 
: its child object, and its motion is governed by 
: user defined equations. These equations consist of 
: any number of temporary variable definitions and 
: a final definition line. This structure allow 
: complex equations to be modelled easily.

: This method of mechanism modelling allows Workspace to simulate
: any mechanism type including the Stewart Platform and the Neos 
: Tricept robot.

: 
: The 


</textarea>
<p>

    <center>
      <h1>Info</h1>
    </center>
<hr size=7 width=75%>
<center>[ <a href="#followups">Follow Ups</a> ] [ <a href="#postfp">Post Followup</a> ] [ <a href="http://www.rosl.com/wwwboard/wwwboard.html">Workspace User Group</a> ] [ <a href="http://www.rosl.com/wwwboard/faq.html">FAQ</a> ]</center>
<hr size=7 width=75%><p>
Posted by <a href="mailto:tiberio@tecnomare.nettuno.it">Tiberio Grasso</a> on June 06, 1996 at 05:00:43:<p>
-Is it possible to have some modifications in the <br>standard software?<br>-In particular:<br>we need two 'virtual cameras' attached to a specific<br>reference frame, fixed or moving with respect to base.<br>Note that in this case a perspective view is needed, and<br>also a specific window where to input the relevant data.<br>-As regards forward and inverse dynamics, I know that<br>with the use of a DLL it is possible to perform these<br>operations. But what must I write in these DLLs?
<br>

HTTP/1.0 200 OK

<html>
  <head>
    <title>Re: Moving views &amp; dynamics</title>
  </head>
  <body>
    <center>
      <h1>Re: Moving views &amp; dynamics</h1>
    </center>
<hr size=7 width=75%>
<center>[ <a href="#followups">Follow Ups</a> ] [ <a href="#postfp">Post Followup</a> ] [ <a href="http://www.rosl.com/wwwboard/wwwboard.html">Workspace User Group</a> ] [ <a href="http://www.rosl.com/wwwboard/faq.html">FAQ</a> ]</center>
<hr size=7 width=75%><p>
Posted by <a href="mailto:james@rosl.demon.co.uk">James Potter</a> on June 07, 1996 at 02:19:33:<p>
In Reply to: <a href="25.html">Info</a> posted by Tiberio Grasso on June 06, 1996 at 05:00:43:<p>
: -Is it possible to have some modifications in the <br>: standard software?<br>: -In particular:<br>: we need two 'virtual cameras' attached to a specific<br>: reference frame, fixed or moving with respect to base.<br>: Note that in this case a perspective view is needed, and<br>: also a specific window where to input the relevant data.<br>: -As regards forward and inverse dynamics, I know that<br>: with the use of a DLL it is possible to perform these<br>: operations. But what must I write in these DLLs?<p>1. VIRTUAL CAMERAS (ATTACHED TO MOVING OBJECT)<br>A Geometry Point is attached to the moving object, there <br>is a Workspace command (VIEW) that sets the position/<br>direction of eye.  A background track is run that <br>continually checks the GP's position and adjusts the <br>view accordingly.<p>2. PERSPECTIVE. <br>This is available in Workspace.<p>5. INPUT WINDOW<br>Reading from user (PROMPTUSER command) is possible.<p>4. DYNAMICS.<br>We supply an example pascal dynamics file (to <br>be compiled to a dll).I will fax section from the <br>Workspace User Guide on "Writing your own dynamics <br>routines".<p>
<br>
<br><hr size=7 width=75%><p>
<a name="followups">Follow Ups:</a><br>
<ul><!--insert: 26-->
</ul><!--end: 26-->
<br><hr size=7 width=75%><p>
<a name="postfp">Post a Followup</a><p>
<form method=POST action="http://www.rosl.com/my-cgi-bin/wwwboard.cgi">
<input type=hidden name="followup" value="25,26">
<input type=hidden name="origname" value="James Potter">
<input type=hidden name="origemail" value="james@rosl.demon.co.uk">

<input type=hidden name="origdate" value="June 07, 1996 at 02:19:33">

Subject: <input type=text name="subject"value="Re: Moving views &amp; dynamics" size=50><p>
Comments:<br>
<textarea name="body" COLS=50 ROWS=10>
: : -Is it possible to have some modifications in the 
: : standard software?
: : -In particular:
: : we need two 'virtual cameras' attached to a specific
: : reference frame, fixed or moving with respect to base.
: : Note that in this case a perspective view is needed, and
: : also a specific window where to input the relevant data.
: : -As regards forward and inverse dynamics, I know that
: : with the use of a DLL it is possible to perform these
: : operations. But what must I write in these DLLs?

: 1. VIRTUAL CAMERAS (ATTACHED TO MOVING OBJECT)
: A Geometry Point is attached to the moving object, there 
: is a Workspace command (VIEW) that sets the position/
: direction of eye.  A background track is run that 
: continually checks the GP's position and adjusts the 
: view accordingly.

: 2. PERSPECTIVE. 
: This is available in Workspace.

: 5. INPUT WINDOW
: Reading from user (PROMPTUSER command) is possible.

: 4. DYNAMICS.
: We supply an example pascal dynamics file (to 
: be compiled to a dll).I will fax section from the 
: Workspace User Guide on &quot;Writing your own dynamics 
: routines&quot;.

</textarea>

<TITLE>Upgrade your browser to recognise VRML</TITLE> 
</HEAD>
<BODY background="paper3.gif">
<H1>Upgrade your browser to recognise VRML</H1> 

<P>If your browser does not recognise VRML files then click on one of the following.</P>

<P><B><U>Note that the Netscape VRML extension entitled 'Moving Worlds Plug-In' is in Beta-test. This means that it may contain bugs which should be reported to Netscape and which are not the responsibility of Robot Simulations Ltd. The Moving Worlds Beta-test is designed to disable many of its features after May 31st 1996 and so will have to be renewed after that date. Please read the Netscape license for more information.</U></B></P> 

<UL>
<LI>
<A HREF="http://www.microsoft.com/kb/peropsys/win95/q141474.htm">VRML upgrade for Microsoft Internet Explorer 2.0</A>

<LI>
<A HREF="http://home.netscape.com/comprod/products/navigator/live3d/index.html">VRML upgrade (Moving Worlds) Beta-test for Netscape Navigator 2.0</A>

<LI>
<A HREF="http://www.sdsc.edu/vrml/">Select another VRML browser</A>

</UL>

<center><IMG SRC="line_col.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></img></center>

<HEAD>
<TITLE>Industrial Case-Study: A Water-jet Cutting Workcell</TITLE> 
<BODY background="paper3.gif">
<H1>Industrial Case-Study: A Water-jet Cutting Workcell</H1> 
</HEAD>

<H2>by John Owens (RSL) and Kevin Piatkowsky (RPT)</H2>


<H3>Background</H3>

<P>RPT is a robot systems integrator with special knowledge of Water-jet cutting applications using Fanuc robots. They use very high pressure water jets varying in pressure from 40,000 to 55,000 psi depending on the type and width of the material to be cut. The distilled water is run through three filters (10, 1, and 0.5 micron thick) to filter out any particles and then passed through flexible metal tubing along the length of the robot to a nozzle attached as a tool to the end of the robot.
Materials that can be cut in this way include fibre-glass, headliner material, carpet, plastic (hard and soft). With the addition of an abrasive named garnet (with the texture of sand) it becomes possible to cut sheet metal or even marble: RPT have developed workcells that can cut more than 3 inches of aluminium or 2 inches of steel. Water-jet cutting is very cost-efficient in comparison to other methods such as laser-jet cutting. It is particularly suitable for cutting soft fabrics, causes no heat-stress on the part (it is its own cooling system), and the water can be easily recycled or drained straight into the sewer.</P>

<H3>The Requirements</H3>

<P>The pelt to be cut is 27 millimetres thick. RPT were requested to make two cuts (see figure 1). The first cut would be at a 54 degree angle to the surface.  There were additional specifications as to the length and width of the pelt, from cut line to cut line on the surface.  There was also a radius in each corner of 10 millimetres on the surface. It was required that the 54 degree cut angle be maintained throughout the radius. 
The second cut was to be done at an 80 degree angle to the upper surface.  This cut was to be made on the already existing 'slope' of the 54 degree cut.  This would mean that the overall length and width of the part should be measured at its widest point on the 'peak' of the edges.  Again there were specified lengths and widths for this 'peak' as well as the bottom surface cut line to cut line.  Again there was a specific radius that had to maintain this 80 degree cut angle. There was also a specification that this 'peak' had to be 13 millimetres from the surface, and had to be maintained at this consistent height around the whole part, especially the corners.  Angles needed to be maintained +/- 2 degrees.  Dimensions needed to be maintained +/- 1 millimetre.</P>

<center><IMG SRC="rpt1.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></center>
<center>Figure 1 - The part specification</center>

<H3>The Workcell</H3>
<P>The workcell is shown in figure 2. It consists of a Fanuc S500 robot using an S3 controller and the TP robot language. Four parts are cut from one pelt before the cut parts are unloaded and the next pelt placed in the workcell.</P>

<H3>The First Attempt: Manual Programming</H3>
<P>The first attempt to solve the problem involved teaching the robot by hand using the Fanuc teach-pendant.  This required a great deal of time and patience to teach the hundreds of points required for each of the four cuts.</P>
<P>Although the programmer could fine tune points taught by eye by entering numbers calculated using the mathematics of the part, it was still extremely difficult to ensure that the angle of the cuts was consistent.</P>
<P>A further problem was that the cuts were not repeatable over the four parts. Because of the distortion in the robot envelope due to the geometric structure of the robot the points used to cut a part in one area of the pelt when transferred to another area of the pelt gave less consistent cuts.</P>
<P>Water-jet cutting is a very demanding application because any deviation that the robot makes in its path, any change in velocity, any defect in the robot will show up in the final part.</P>
<P>After about 40 hours of programming the parts being cut were still not of the quality required.</P>

<H3>The Solution:Simulation,Calibration and Offline Programming using Workspace/Robotrak</H3>

<P>RPT chose to use a robot simulation software package named Workspace to perform the simulation, calibration, and offline programming of the workcell. The key factors in this decision were as follows:</P>
<P>1. Workspace is integrated with the Robotrak robot and tool calibration system. This close integration means that robot and tool calibration (for both the tool offset and orientation) is quick and effective.</P>
<P>2. Workspace allow users to work in the robot's native language, in this case TP. This provides users with the entire power of the TP language, without the need for postprocessing of any kind. Offline programming is therefore a one-step process.</P>
<P>3. The Workspace CAD, simulation, and offline programming system is quick and easy to use. This enabled the workcell to be designed.</P>
<P>4. Workspace can run on any IBM-compatible PC. The cost of the hardware required for the simulation was therefore kept to a minimum, and existing PCs at present used for other purposes might be used. Workspace can also run on a notebook. This enables the engineers involved in modifications in the workcell to work on the shopfloor if required.</P>
<P>5. Robotrak is easy to set up and use, even in a clustered workcell, since the three base units that must be placed on the floor can be placed anywhere in the workcell.</P>

<H3>The Method</H3>
<P>First one part was modelled using the Workspace CAD system as a series of closed polylines (linked arcs and lines). The geometry points required along each polyline (representing the meeting point of the water-jet and the part) were taught within Workspace along the polyline. These geometry points are like robot teachpoints except that they are stored with the model and may therefore be easily moved in the model independently of the robot.</P>
<P>The user defined only start and end geometry points on a given line or arc - Workspace then used interpolation to automatically create intermediate geometry points along the lines or arcs at a distance between each point defined by the programmer. This technique of over defining the path (using more points than might seem necessary) ensures that the robot follows the path more precisely.</P>
<P>The part was then copied four times and placed within the workcell. This also copies and moves the geometry points four times so that they do not need to be redefined for each part.</P>
<P>The Fanuc S500 robot model was loaded from the robot library and placed within the workcell. If the placing of the robot was such that any of the geometry points were unachievable then the geometry points were displayed in red. The robot could then be repositioned. Figure 2 shows the Workspace model of the workcell and Figure 3 shows the geometry points defined on a part.</P>

<center><IMG SRC="rpt2.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></center>
<center>Figure 2 - The Workspace model of the workcell</center>

<center><IMG SRC="rpt3.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></center>
<center>Figure 3 - Geometry points defined on a part</center>

<P>The robot programme was defined from the Workspace menus in the TP language using movements to the geometry points and the necessary motion types, motion termination types, and velocities. If movement along the path caused the robot to hit a limit on one of the wrist joints, or when moving from one cut to the next cut, then an additional move was inserted to enable the wrist to re-orientate itself (known as an air move).</P>
<P>After the robot programme was defined from the Workspace menus then the Workspace text editor was used to inspect and comment the different parts of the programme, as well as to add commands for turning the water jet on or off.
The next stage was to calibrate the robot and tool (see Figure 4) using Robotrak. A special fitting had been designed that screwed the robotrak cords onto the end of the water-jet. The robot was then moved to 50 teachpoints all with different positions and orientations throughout the envelope, and Workspace automatically took an xyz measurement reading from Robotrak each time the robot paused between movements.</P>

<center><IMG SRC="rpt4.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></center>
<center>Figure 4 - Robot and tool calibration using Robotrak</center>

<P>The teachpoint file and the measurement file were then used in Workspace to instigate a search which in 1 minute found the joint angle offsets, errors in link lengths, misalignment of joint axes, tool xyz offset, and joint compliances, which together make up the signature of the robot.</P>
<P>Two additional fittings were used to take two additional measurements using Robotrak and thereby find the true tool orientation (see Figure 5).</P>

<center><IMG SRC="rpt5.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></center>
<center>Figure 5 - Robotrak fittings for end of water-jet tool (from left to right): for measuring 50 points; for measuring tool z-axis, for measuring tool x-axis; for teaching points on part.</center>

<P>Robotrak was then disconnected from the robot and a pointer attached to the end of the water-jet tool. This pointer was used to teach three teachpoints which just touched each of the four pelts. By taking these teachpoints back into Workspace and comparing them with the geometry points taught on the pelts it was possible to update the model for the true position of the pelts.</P>
<P>The robot programme was then downloaded to the robot using the Workspace Send to robot command. This converts all the geometry points in the programme into teachpoints, uses the robot and tool signature to correct the accuracy of the points, merges the teachpoint file and programme file and compiles it to a binary .TP file, and then copies the file into the robot subdirectory.</P>

<H3>The Results</H3>
<P>It took about 10 hours to complete the whole simulation, calibration and offline programme the 4 parts and their programmes, compared to the 40 hours plus for the programming alone.</P>
<P>These programmes were then applied to the robot with the calibration package, the tooling was calibrated with a tool fixture, and the first cut proved more consistently accurate in terms of cut angle and position than any manually taught programme was able to achieve.</P>
<P>The programme created using Workspace and Robotrak ran first time on the robot controller without any modifications. No touch up was required using the teach pendant.</P>

<H3>Summary</H3>
<P>Robot simulation, calibration, and offline programming produced parts that were cut to a higher accuracy than those cut using manually taught methods. The time taken to programme an accurate path was also reduced drastically. No manual touch up of the points was required primarily because the real-world had been accurately simulated using the Workspace/Robotrak robot, tool, and model calibration methods.</P>

<center><IMG SRC="line_col.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></img></center>


<P ALIGN=center><A HREF="index.htm"><IMG SRC="home.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></a>[ <A HREF="index.htm">Return to Home Page</A> ]</P> 

<center><IMG SRC="line_col.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></img></center>


<center><h6><b>Workspace</b> and <b>Robotrak</b> are registered trademarks of Robot Simulations Ltd.</h6>

<h6>Copyright &copy; 1996 Robot Simulations Ltd</h6>
<h6>Last revision 3 April 1996</h6></center>
</P>



</BODY>

</HTML>


</DOC>

<HEAD>
</HEAD>
<BODY BACKGROUND="paper3.gif">
<TITLE>British Gas Research and Technology Division - Design of an intelligent test rig for pre-paid gas metering schemes</TITLE> 
<H1>British Gas Research and Technology Division - Design of an intelligent test rig for pre-paid gas metering schemes</H1> 


<H2>Workspace user profile</H2>
<P>British Gas are the UK's primary commercial and domestic gas supplier. For many years they have installed coin-operated gas meters to meet the needs of certain customers. Because these meters hold coins, they have proved to be targets for vandalism and theft. British Gas Research and technology division have therefore developed several schemes for meters which use plastic keys, magnetic strip cards and smart cards as a credit medium.</P>

<H2>The challenge</H2>
<P>A test rig had to be implemented to assess the reliability of the payment schemes outlined above before embarking on a nation-wide installation programme.</P>

<P>The test rig had to pick up the keys or cards from feeds, then insert and remove them from the meters. In the case of the cards, it was necessary to place each one into a card programming device first. All results were to be logged automatically on a PC.</P>

<H2>The solution</H2>

<P>The first step in the design of the test rig was to use Workspace to try out various layout ideas and compare the performance of different robots for the application.</P>

<P>The robot, gas meter, card programmer, feeding mechanism and other components were all modelled using the simulation's integrated CAD system. then, several different industrial robots were placed in the Workspace computer model and tested. The most appropriate layout was quickly found by comparing the times for one complete test cycle.</P>

<P>After evaluation on the simulator, an Alpha2 robot was chosen as the ideal robot. The robot was subsequently purchased and the test rig was built.</P>

<H2>British Gas' financial justification for Workspace</H2>

<P>Simulation using Workspace enabled different robots to be evaluated for the task before purchase.</P>

<P>The test rig was built on a "right first time" basis.</P>

<P>Workspace prevented costly mistakes during the development of the project.</P>

1993 Robot Simulations Ltd.
C.G.Ariss
<center><IMG SRC="line_col.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></img></center>


<P ALIGN=center><A HREF="index.htm"><IMG SRC="gif/home.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></a>[ <A HREF="index.htm">Return to Home Page</A> ]</P> 

<center><IMG SRC="line_col.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></img></center>


<center><h6><b>Workspace</b> and <b>Robotrak</b> are registered trademarks of Robot Simulations Ltd.</h6>

<h6>Copyright &copy; 1996 Robot Simulations Ltd</h6>
<h6>Last revision 3 April 1996</h6></center>
</P>



</BODY>

<HEAD>
<TITLE>Glaxo Group Research Ltd - Robot Motion Simulation In Support Of System Design, Application Development, Management Decision Making And User Training</TITLE> 
</HEAD>
<BODY background="paper3.gif"
<H1>Glaxo Group Research Ltd - Robot Motion Simulation In Support Of System Design, Application Development, Management Decision Making And User Training</H1> 

<H2>Workspace user profile</H2>

<P>Glaxo Group Research Ltd are part of the pharmaceutical giant Glaxo. They are based in Hertfordshire, England and have large research laboratories there. Their BioEngineering unit is engaged in research to develop automated systems in support of innovative laboratory procedures to improve effectiveness, quality, safety and productivity in development of ethical pharmaceuticals.</P>

<H2>The challenge</H2>
<P>Skilled laboratory staff currently spend 25% of their time performing the tedious and repetitive job of accessing the company's large reference collection of pharmaceutical compounds. Installing an automated storage and retrieval system would free those laboratory staff to concentrate on other work.</P>

<P>Before an installation can take place, the design under consideration must be "proven" to work. The conventional approach for Glaxo is to take drawings of the design and use them to build "non-functional" models whose sole purpose is to illustrate the design concept. The next stage is to build a moving "proof of principle" model with which to investigate the functional capability of the system.</P>

<P>Speed of development is a key issue, and Glaxo purchased Workspace to provide additional capability to their design department.</P>

<H2>The solution</H2>
<P>Glaxo's proposed solution is to install a completely new design of robotic storage and retrieval system.</P>

<P>The arrangement was modelled on Workspace and moving devices simulated. Workspace enabled the BioEngineering department to check that the design achieved its specification. In addition, estimates of retrieval times were automatically calculated to judge the efficiency of the system. Using Workspace, the model can be changed effortlessly to experiment with alternative layouts.</P>

<P>A moving animation of the design clearly communicated the concept to management and end users, promoting informed discussion and leading to the system's optimisation, acceptance and approval.</P>

<H2>The future</H2>

<P>Mike Duncan of Glaxo Group Research stated that, in future Workspace will be used as follows:-</P>
<P>"Illustrate the proposed arrangements of automated systems; it will offer, in addition, the opportunity to experiment quickly and cheaply with alternative layouts."<P>

<P>"Ensure that the physical layout of the system does not clash with the surrounding environment and related equipment either at rest or at any point in its operational cycle."</P>

<P>"Optimise the functional design and operational procedure of the system during development to ensure that the first-off, which may be the only example, requires little or no  modification to achieve the standard of structural integrity and behavioural refinement required for performance critical applications in a sophisticated science-oriented environment."</P>

<P>"Workspace will reduce the need to build models and will provide a basis for 'right-first-time' development of special purpose laboratory automation."</P>

<H2>Glaxo's financial justification for Workspace</H2>
<P>Faster accomplishment of automation projects.</P>
<P>Reduced requirement for rectification during system development prior to commissioning.</P>
<P>Reduced requirement for physical models during the planning, design and development programme.</P>

1993 Robot Simulations Ltd. C.G.Ariss
<center><IMG SRC="line_col.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></img></center>


<P ALIGN=center><A HREF="index.htm"><IMG SRC="home.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></a>[ <A HREF="index.htm">Return to Home Page</A> ]</P> 

<center><IMG SRC="line_col.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></img></center>


<center><h6><b>Workspace</b> and <b>Robotrak</b> are registered trademarks of Robot Simulations Ltd.</h6>

<h6>Copyright &copy; 1996 Robot Simulations Ltd</h6>
<h6>Last revision 3 April 1996</h6></center>
</P>

<HEAD>
<TITLE>Cimtas AS - Optimising reach and off-line programming in an arc welding workcell</TITLE> 
</HEAD>
<BODY background="paper3.gif">
<H1>Cimtas AS - Optimising reach and off-line programming in an arc welding workcell</H1> 

<H2>Workspace user profile</H2>

<P>Cimtas are a Turkish company involved in the construction industry. They specialise in the fabrication and installation of heavy steel structures, cranes and pressure vessels. They manufacture in the region of 24,000 tonnes of steel structures per year and have over 1800 employees.</P>

<H2>The challenge</H2>

<P>Cimtas arc weld large I-beams on their production line and have recently purchased both Fanuc Arcmate and REIS SRV12L robots to form part of their manufacturing system.</P>

fig.1

fig.2

<P>The I-beams are placed on a rotating table mechanism (D) which may be positioned manually along a linear track (C). by an operator (See fig.1). Once the beam is in place, the rotating overhead mechanism (A) swings the robot across into the appropriate position to start welding. Height of the robot above the floor may be adjusted manually at B.</P>

<P>Before using Workspace, the robot program was generated entirely by using the teach pendant on the shop floor. Since 9 axes are used, it can be difficult for the operator to visualise all possible configurations. Due to the size of the I-beams, Cimtas have encountered many problems in getting the robots to achieve satisfactory welds without exceeding a robot joint limit or having the welding tool collide with the workpiece. It is possible to move the robot up and down along the vertical track B, but only by unbolting it and winching it into position. This makes it difficult to experiment with different heights above the floor.</P>

<H2>Project aims</H2>
<P>To experiment with different robot and table configurations to maximise the work envelope.</P>

<P>To minimise the possibility of a collision when the robot re-orients itself during its task.</P>

<P>To improve safety for the human operator.</P>

<P>To reduce the need for teach pendant programming.</P>

<P>To optimise the robot program and reduce cycle time.</P>

<H2>The solution</H2>
<P>A model of the workcell was created with Workspace and the SRV12L and Arcmate were compared for reachability. The Workspace facility to plot the working envelope was used to position the work piece optimally. It was immediately found that in this application, the Reis SRV12L robot allowed a greater working envelope, so this robot was chosen in place of the Arcmate for the workcell.</P>

<P>By using Workspace it was possible to make the vertical track B a translational joint on the rotating column A. This allowed the height of the robot to be optimised by simply changing a variable in the simulation. Work then began on developing a set of teach points which the robot could follow without hitting a joint limit or colliding with the workpiece.</P>

<P>It was found that repositioning the column A between welds enabled several particularly difficult moves to be achieved. Previously, Cimtas had simply placed the mechanism so that it was at right angles to the linear track C for the duration of the cycle.</P>

<P>Collisions tended to arise if the robot was forced to reorient the wrist during a linear move along a welding seam. The simulation highlights any collisions and allows the user to abandon a move and immediately try another approach.</P>

<H2>Cimtas' financial justification for Workspace</H2>

<P>A complete set of teach points to perform the task was generated. These teach points were later used directly in a new program generated on Cimtas' text-based off line programming system.</P>

<P>Time to develop the new program was reduced by over 40%.</P>

<P>Development of the new program was achieved off-line while the robot was operating.</P>

<P>A technical decision was made to use only Reis robots for the larger workpieces in Cimtas's manufacturing workcell.</P>

<P>The risk of damage to personnel and equipment was eliminated.</P>

1993 Robot Simulations Ltd.
C.G.Ariss

<center><IMG SRC="line_col.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></img></center>

<HTML>
<HEAD>
<TITLE>University of Plymouth: The Foundation Of a New Course - BSc Robotics & Automation Systems</TITLE>
<body background="paper3.gif"> 
<H1>University of Plymouth: The Foundation Of a New Course - BSc Robotics & Automation Systems</H1> 
</HEAD>

<H2>Workspace user profile</H2>
<P>The University of Plymouth is the first UK university to offer a course in Robotics & Automation Systems. The course has been developed to address the need for graduate engineers with a good knowledge of automated manufacturing systems.</P>

<H2>The challenge</H2>
<P>An essential theme in the course is that of practical "hands-on" experience of robots. The University currently has eleven small educational robots and an industrial ABB IRB1000.</P>

<p>To date, students have had to work in teams, having access to the robots only during laboratory sessions. Clearly more industrial robots had to be made available to provide students with the necessary access to modern robotic hardware. An ideal solution would be to provide each student with their own robot, which they could use at any time in complete safety.</P>

<P>The prohibitive cost of industrial robots is only the first barrier to the undertaking of such a course. Student safety is also a prime consideration. Additional staff would be needed to supervise laboratory sessions and access at other times would be impossible.</P>

<H2>The solution</H2>
<P>Combining practical laboratory sessions with Workspace provided the answer. The simulation system is now used as the foundations for all robotic modules on the course. Students may use Workspace to load a model of an industrial robot, create a workcell using the integrated CAD system and write robot programs. This can be done at any time of the day using one of the University's PCs.</P>

<P>Students may even construct their own mechanisms in Workspace and experiment with different controller parameters, plotting graphs to show the effect on robot dynamics.</P>

<P>Simulated robotic projects can be developed in complete safety. In addition, the newly introduced Computer Assisted Learning (CAL) features in Workspace have enabled the creation of interactive training exercises by course tutors.</P>

<P>The University now intends to start an active Workspace users group which will pool CAL material world-wide from a wide range of institutions.</P>

<H2>Benefits</H2>
<P>Savings on robotic hardware allowed more students to enrol</P>
<P>Use of simulation software made the course more attractive to prospective students</P>
<P>Safety problems were overcome</P>
<P>Students could apply newly learnt principles outside of laboratory sessions</P>

<H2>The University's financial justification for Workspace</H2>

<P>Establishment of the course would not have been possible without a simulation system</P>

<P>Workspace provides the best possible price/performance ratio</P>

<P>Academic staff were free to concentrate on teaching rather than safety supervision</P>

1993 Robot Simulations Ltd.
C.G.Ariss

<center><IMG SRC="line_col.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></img></center>


<P ALIGN=center><A HREF="index.htm"><IMG SRC="home.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></a>[ <A HREF="index.htm">Return to Home Page</A> ]</P> 

<center><IMG SRC="line_col.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></img></center>

<h6>Copyright &copy; 1996 Robot Simulations Ltd</h6>
<h6>Last revision 3 April 1996</h6></center>
</P>

<HEAD>
<TITLE>Komatsu UK - Design of a new arc welding workcell</TITLE> 
</HEAD>
<body background="paper3.gif">
<H1>Komatsu UK - Design of a new arc welding workcell</H1> 

<H2>Workspace user profile</H2>

<P>Komatsu UK manufacture and export a range of excavators worldwide. Their production line is highly automated, using robots to improve quality in the construction of large, steel components.</P>

<H2>The challenge</H2>

<P>Komatsu needed to build a new workcell for a component that previously had to be welded by hand. The component has a number of difficult seams to weld, requiring the welding torch to fit into a confined space.</P>

<P>The component is approximately 2m long and is constructed using steel plate. The welding seams must lie horizontally with the welding torch making an angle of 45 degrees between adjacent faces.</P>

<P>The torch moves at about 15cm per minute, so the part must be positioned carefully for a good weld.</P>

<P>The weld illustrated as A-B in the diagram opposite is a particularly difficult one since the welding torch must fit between two plates to get to the seam.</P>

<H2>Project Aims</H2>
<P>Weld at least 80% of the seams by robot</P>

<P>Design and evaluate an appropriate positioning device</P>

<P>Evaluate the robot's welding torch design</P>

<P>Test for collisions</P>

<H2>The solution</H2>
<P>The Komatsu robot (KHY660) was modelled on Workspace and the component was imported in the form of a DXF file. Once this was done a model of a positioner was created.</P>

<P>Originally, a positioner with 3 axes was to be built especially for this task. However, since this was expensive, Komatsu wished to evaluate a spare positioner they had at the plant. This NEI Thompson 2-axis positioner was left over from a previous job but did not appear to offer the same flexibility as the original positioner design.</P>

<P>Workspace was used to test whether this positioner could place the component correctly for all welding seams.</P>

<P>Here is a diagram of the final proposed workcell:-</P>
 
<P>(Note that the clamps used to secure the part to the positioner are not shown.)</P>

<P>The robot work envelope is shown hatched in the diagram to the right and the torch is shown on the weld A-B.</P>

<P>On attempting to "weld" the part, Workspace demonstrated that part of the robot tool would collide with the component in the proposed layout. By interactively changing the positioner joint angles it was discovered that there was one position where the tool could perform the weld without collisions.</P>

<P>The new design (using the 2-axis positioner) was proved to be more effective than the original proposal.</P>

<P>All welds were found to be within reach, although the welding torch length was to be reduced to provide adequate clearance along seam A-B.</P>

<P>The 2-axis positioner exceeded expectations, since it was also capable of carrying a different component for another task within the same workcell setup.</P>

<H2>Komatsu's financial justification for Workspace</H2>

<P>By recycling an unused positioner, cost savings in excess of 60,000 were made.</P>

<P>Time to develop the system was significantly reduced.</P>

<P>Komatsu kept full control over the design process.</P>

1994 Robot Simulations Ltd.
C.G.Ariss
<center><IMG SRC="line_col.gif" ALT="[IMAGE]"></img></center>

<h6>Copyright &copy; 1996 Robot Simulations Ltd</h6>
<h6>Last revision 3 April 1996</h6></center>
</P>
