<H1><A NAME="Header_47" HREF="icsurmst.html#ToC_47">Part 3. Using your server</A></H1>
<HR>
<H1><A NAME="HDRSTR" HREF="icsur006.html#PToC_48">Chapter 5. Starting to use your server</A></H1>
Using Your Server
<P>
This chapter contains basic instructions
for starting and stopping your server.
It also describes the first tasks you will
probably want to perform after installation.
<P>
<P><A HREF="icsurmst.html#ToC">Partial Table-of-Contents</A>
<MENU>
<LI><A NAME=PToC_49 HREF="#HDRSTRSTO" >Starting the server</A>
<MENU>
<LI><A NAME=PToC_50 HREF="#Header_50" >Starting automatically from the OS/2 startup folder</A>
<LI><A NAME=PToC_51 HREF="#Header_51" >Starting from the Internet Connection Secure Server icon</A>
<LI><A NAME=PToC_52 HREF="#Header_52" >Starting from the command prompt</A>
<LI><A NAME=PToC_53 HREF="#Header_53" >Starting multiple instances of the server</A>
<LI><A NAME=PToC_54 HREF="#Header_54" >Restarting from the Internet Connection Secure Server Window</A>
</MENU>
<LI><A NAME=PToC_55 HREF="#Header_55" >Stopping the server</A>
<LI><A NAME=PToC_56 HREF="#HDRVIEWFP" >Viewing your server's Front Page</A>
<LI><A NAME=PToC_57 HREF="#HDRWHTNXT" >What's next?</A>
</MENU><HR><P>
<P>
<HR>
<H2><A NAME="HDRSTRSTO" HREF="#PToC_49">Starting the server</A></H2>
<P>
This section describes how to start and stop your server
after you have finished installing it.
If you think the server is running but you do not see the window
for it on your OS/2 Desktop, press <B>Ctrl+Esc</B>
to see the list of active OS/2 programs.
If the Window List contains an entry for the server, double click
the entry to bring the server's window into view.
<P>
If you are running a non-secure server,
you will see the message
<TT>Security not available. <VAR>filename</VAR>.dll did not load</TT>.
This message lets you know that you are not running the Internet Connection Secure Server.
You do not need to do anything in response to the message.
<P>
<H3><A NAME="Header_50" HREF="#PToC_50">Starting automatically from the OS/2 startup folder</A></H3>
<P>
If during installation you checked Auto Start Server at Bootup,
the server has been added to your OS/2 Startup folder.
Each time you start or reboot your system, the server will start.
If you rebooted your system after installing the server,
the server should be running now.
<P>
When you start the server automatically,
it uses the current configuration settings.
If you have not changed the server configuration since installation,
the current configuration is based on the information you
entered during installation along with defaults.
<P>
<H3><A NAME="Header_51" HREF="#PToC_51">Starting from the Internet Connection Secure Server icon</A></H3>
<P>
The installation procedure creates an Internet Connection Secure Server
folder on your OS/2 Desktop.
Inside the folder is an icon for the Internet Connection Secure Server.
To start the server, double click the icon.
<P>
The server starts with the current configuration settings.
If you have not changed the server configuration since installation,
the current configuration is based on the information you
entered during installation along with defaults.
<P>
<H3><A NAME="Header_52" HREF="#PToC_52">Starting from the command prompt</A></H3>
<P>
You can start the server from any OS/2 command prompt by entering:
<P>&nbsp;
<PRE>
<B>httpd</B>
</PRE>
<P>
This starts the server with the current configuration settings.
If you have not changed the server configuration since installation,
the current configuration is based on the information you
entered during installation along with defaults.
<P>
The httpd command also accepts various options for changing
configuration settings at run time.
For details on the httpd command options,
see the <CITE>Webmaster&#39;s Guide</CITE>.
<P>
<H3><A NAME="Header_53" HREF="#PToC_53">Starting multiple instances of the server</A></H3>
<P>
You can start multiple instances of the server,
but each instance must listen on a separate port.
All instances, other than the first, can be started
by entering the following command from a command prompt:
<P>
<B>httpd -r <VAR>other_rule_file</VAR></B>
<P>
where <VAR>other_rule_file</VAR> is a configuration file that
specifies the individual port.
<P>
<H3><A NAME="Header_54" HREF="#PToC_54">Restarting from the Internet Connection Secure Server Window</A></H3>
<P>
You can restart your server from the Internet Connection Secure Server window
by selecting <B>Restart</B>
from the <B>Server</B> pull-down menu on the menu bar.
The server reloads the configuration settings from
the configuration file it was originally started with.
<HR>
<H2><A NAME="Header_55" HREF="#PToC_55">Stopping the server</A></H2>
<P>
You can stop the server the same ways you stop other OS/2 programs.
Do any of the following:
<UL>
<P><LI>Go to the Internet Connection Secure Server window and double click
the small icon in the top left corner.
<P><LI>Go to the Internet Connection Secure Server window and select <B>Exit</B> from the
<B>Server</B> pull-down menu on the menu bar.
<P><LI>Go to the Internet Connection Secure Server window and press <B>F3</B>.
<P><LI>Press <B>Ctrl+Esc</B>.
With the right mouse button click the Window List entry for the Internet Connection Secure Server.
Click <B>Close</B>.
</UL>
<HR>
<H2><A NAME="HDRVIEWFP" HREF="#PToC_56">Viewing your server's Front Page</A></H2>
<P>
After your server is up and running, you can use WebExplorer or
any other Web browser to look at the server's Front Page.
<P>
If you started the server with the default configuration file
and you have not yet created your own home page,
you can view the Front Page by using your
browser to open the following URL:
<P>&nbsp;
<PRE>
<B>http://<VAR>your.server.name</VAR>/</B>
</PRE>
<P>Where <VAR>your.server.name</VAR> is
the fully qualified name of your host.
For example, http://www.ibm.com/.
<P>
The server's Front Page contains the following links:
<UL>
<P><LI><B>Configuration and Administration Forms</B>.  A tool that lets
you configure your server by filling in a set of forms.
The forms are coded with the Hypertext Markup Language (HTML).
<P><LI><B>Sample Home Page</B>.  A sample document
that demonstrates how to use many of the HTML tags.
<P><LI><B>Internet Connection Family Web Site</B>.  From this Web
site, you can download beta versions of software under development,
product giveaways, accessory code, demo code, and other goodies.
You can also learn more about our retail products.
<P><LI><B>Documentation</B>.  An online HTML version of the following:
<UL COMPACT>
<LI><CITE>Quick Beginnings</CITE>
<LI><CITE>Webmaster's Guide</CITE>
<LI><CITE>Web Programming Guide</CITE>
<LI><CITE>Web design information</CITE>
</UL>
</UL>
<P>
If you want to go to the Front Page after you create your own home
page, just include the Front Page file name on the URL.
The Front Page file name is Frntpage.html,
so you would use the following URL to see it:
<P>&nbsp;
<PRE>
<B>http://<VAR>your.server.name</VAR>/Frntpage.html</B>
</PRE>
<HR>
<H2><A NAME="HDRWHTNXT" HREF="#PToC_57">What's next?</A></H2>
<P>
Now that your server is up and running, you'll probably
want to configure it to your own specifications.
Your server allows you to:
<UL>
<P><LI><B>Modify the Configuration and Administration forms</B>
to easily configure the default settings.
<P><LI><B>Change the default home page</B>
to have the server return your own home page.
The home page is the document that your server returns when a client
sends a request that does not point to a specific directory or file.
<P><LI><B>Change your document root directory</B>
to serve requests that do not point to a specific directory.
Your home page should always be on your home directory.
<P><LI><B>Run your server as a caching proxy</B> to improve
response time by having the proxy server store the documents
it receives from other servers in a local cache.
<P><LI><B>Run a proxy server and standard server</B>
from the same host to have the convenience of running
two different servers from one host.
<P><LI><B>Run your server with multiple IP addresses or virtual
hosts</B> to
serve different files based on the IP address of the network
connection a request comes in on or the host for whom the
request is made.
This is especially helpful for
Internet access providers who want to use one server to provide
Web sites for multiple customers.
</UL>
<P>
These activities are described in the <CITE>Webmaster's Guide</CITE>.
<P><HR><B>&#91; <A HREF="#Top_Of_Page">Top of Page</A> &#124; <A HREF="icsur006.html">Previous Page</A> &#124; <A HREF="icsur008.html">Next Page</A> &#124; <A HREF="icsurmst.html#ToC">Table of Contents</A> &#93;</B>
<A NAME=Bot_Of_Page>&nbsp;</A>
</BODY></HTML>

</DOC>

<HR>
<H1><A NAME="HDRINF" HREF="icsur007.html#PToC_58">Chapter 6. Obtaining additional information</A></H1>
<P>This chapter describes the available online information
and how to view, print, or order copies of this book.
<HR>
<H2><A NAME="Header_59" HREF="icsur007.html#PToC_59">Viewing online information</A></H2>
<P>The server has online help for both the graphical user interface
and for the Configuration and Administration forms.
The server also includes versions of this book in HTML format that
you can view online.
<P>
<H3><A NAME="Header_60" HREF="icsur007.html#PToC_60">Viewing online help</A></H3>
<P>When your server is running, you can get online help from the
Help pull-down menu in the main window.  This help menu includes:
<DL>
<P><DT>General help
<DD>Explains the parts of the main window and its special key functions
<P><DT>Getting started
<DD>Explains how to start, customize, protect, and stop your
server
<P><DT>Help index
<DD>Provides an alphabetical list of all the help topics related to the
server
</DL>
<P>Help is provided for each of the Configuration and
Administration forms.
When using a form, click the help icon to get
step-by-step instructions for using the form.
<P>
<H3><A NAME="HDRVHTMLB" HREF="icsur007.html#PToC_61">Viewing HTML books</A></H3>
<P>To view the HTML version of this book, your server must
be running.
<OL>
<P><LI>Start your server and your Web browser.
<P><LI>Use your Web browser to view the server's Front Page.
<P>Refer to <A HREF="icsur007.html#HDRVIEWFP">"Viewing your server's Front Page"</A> for more information.
<P><LI>Click <B>Documentation</B>.
</OL>
<HR>
<H2><A NAME="Header_62" HREF="icsur007.html#PToC_62">Printing and ordering books</A></H2>
<P>
Hardcopy versions of the <CITE>Quick Beginnings</CITE> book and the
<CITE>Webmaster's Guide</CITE> are available from the
Internet Connection Family Web site or from your IBM authorized dealer
or marketing representative.
<P>
<H3><A NAME="Header_63" HREF="icsur007.html#PToC_63">Printing books from the Web site</A></H3>
<P>
You can download and print a PDF (portable document format) version
of either book by opening the following URL:
<B>http://www.ics.raleigh.ibm.com/</B>.
<P>
<H3><A NAME="Header_64" HREF="icsur007.html#PToC_64">Ordering books</A></H3>
<P>
You can purchase additional printed copies of this book from your IBM
authorized dealer or marketing representative.
<P><HR><B>&#91; <A HREF="#Top_Of_Page">Top of Page</A> &#124; <A HREF="icsur007.html">Previous Page</A> &#124; <A HREF="icsur009.html">Next Page</A> &#124; <A HREF="icsurmst.html#ToC">Table of Contents</A> &#93;</B>

<HR>
<H1><A NAME="Header_65" HREF="icsurmst.html#ToC_65">Part 4. Appendixes</A></H1>
<HR>
<H1><A NAME="HDRCIDSYSL" HREF="icsur007.html#PToC_66">Appendix A. Installing with SystemView</A></H1>
Installing with SystemView
<P>You can use SystemView to install the Internet Connection Server on
unattended workstations using the statements included in
two files called a <I>software profile</I> and a
<I>response file</I>.
A software profile is used by SystemView to
invoke an application installation program.
A response file is used by the installation program to get all of the
data it needs during the installation process.
<P>
Using SystemView, you specify the information for the software profile
and response files when you customize the application definition
file, which defines how to install and configure the Internet Connection Server.
This file is shipped with the Internet Connection Server.
<P>Refer to the SystemView documentation for a complete description
of software profiles and response files.
<HR>
<H2><A NAME="Header_67" HREF="icsur007.html#PToC_67">Overview</A></H2>
<P>To install the Internet Connection Server on server workstations
using SystemView, you need to:
<UL>
<P><LI>Copy the Internet Connection Server files to the code server
<P><LI>Add the Internet Connection Server information to the SystemView software library
<P><LI>Configure the Internet Connection Server in the SystemView software library
by placing it into the catalog at the distribution server
<P><LI>Distribute and install the resulting software object
using SystemView on target server workstations
</UL>
<P>These tasks are described in the following sections.
If you need additional assistance to perform these
tasks, use the online help or refer to
<CITE>SystemView Up and Running&#33;</CITE> for more information.
<HR>
<H2><A NAME="Header_68" HREF="icsur007.html#PToC_68">Copying the Internet Connection Server to the Code Server</A></H2>
<P>
To set up the code server so that you can install the Internet Connection Server
using SystemView, enter the XCOPY command.
<P>
For example, to copy the files from the CD-ROM located in the
E&#58; drive to the D&#58; drive, you would enter this command:
<PRE>
XCOPY E&#58;\*.* D&#58;\CID\IMG\WEB /S
</PRE>
<P>
This command copies the files from the root directory
on the CD-ROM in the E: drive to the D: drive,
putting the files under the directory \CID\IMG\WEB.
<P>
The /S indicates that all of the subdirectories and their contents
and the contents of the root directory should be copied.
<HR>
<H2><A NAME="Header_69" HREF="icsur007.html#PToC_69">Adding the Internet Connection Server to the Software Library</A></H2>
<P>
To add the Internet Connection Server to the software library, do the following steps:
<UL>
<P><LI>Start SystemView.
<P><LI>Double-click on the <B>SystemView Service Manager</B> icon.
<P><LI>Double-click on the <B>CID Software Preparation</B> icon.
<P><LI>Double-click on the <B>Software Library</B> icon.
<P><LI>Select <B>Software</B> from the menu bar
on the Software Library window.
<P><LI>Select <B>New&#46;&#46;&#46;</B>.
<P><LI>Select <B>Find...</B>.
<P><LI>In the Find definition file window, select:
<UL COMPACT>
<LI>The drive letter, where the CD-ROM is located,
in the <B>Drive</B> list
<LI>\ in the <B>Directory</B> list
<LI>www.adf in the <B>File</B> list
</UL>
<P>
This copies the remote installation files (.ADF, .VAR, and .MRF)
from the CD-ROM to the subdirectory where SystemView resides (\SWLIB).
<P><LI>Select <B>Add</B> to associate the application
definition file with the Internet Connection Server.
</UL>
<HR>
<H2><A NAME="HDRCONFSR" HREF="icsur007.html#PToC_70">Configuring the Internet Connection Server</A></H2>
<P>To configure the Internet Connection Server, do the following steps:
<UL>
<P><LI>Double-click on the Internet Connection Server icon in the Software Library window.
<P><LI>Select <B>Configuration</B> from the menu bar on the
Software Configuration window and then select
<B>New&#46;&#46;&#46;</B> from the pull-down window.
</UL>
<P>
The Settings notebook is displayed.
You need to define how the Internet Connection Server will be installed
on the target server workstation.
<P>On each page of the notebook,
select each of the items in the <B>Variables</B>
list and choose the setting.
A description of each variable is displayed in the
<B>Explanation</B> field of the notebook page.
When you have completed all of the pages of the notebook,
click on <B>OK</B>.
If you are ready to distribute the Internet Connection Server, select <B>Yes</B>
when asked <B>Do you want to catalog the database?</B>.
<P>
Here is an overview of just a few of the pages you will fill in.
<DL>
<P><DT><B>Configuration Page
</B><DD>
Use to define both an identifier needed to catalog
the Internet Connection Server uniquely and a name that is a short description
for the configuration you are creating.
For example, the identifier may be <TT>EUROSERV</TT>
and the name may be <TT>Definition for the servers in Europe</TT>.
<P><DT><B>Code Server Page
</B><DD>
Use to associate the configuration with the redirection
mechanism to be used during CID installation.
Define the code server aliases and the CID directory
aliases that let the target workstation (where you want to
install the Internet Connection Server) access the code server images.
You also indicate whether an existing or new response
file will be used.
<P><DT><B>Response File Page
</B><DD>
Use to specify the name and directory where the existing
response file is located.
</DL>
<P>The remaining pages of the Settings notebook configure
the Internet Connection Server at the target server workstation.  SystemView uses
the information from the notebook to create the settings
for the Internet Connection Server variables in the response file.
Refer to the comments in the response file itself
(websrvr.rsp.) for more information about response file keywords.
<HR>
<H2><A NAME="Header_71" HREF="icsur007.html#PToC_71">Installing the Internet Connection Server on a Remote Server Workstation</A></H2>
<P>
To install the Internet Connection Server on a workstation, you can either use
the Event Scheduler or the Remote System Manager.
Refer to
<CITE>SystemView Up and Running&#33;</CITE> for
information on how to use the Event Scheduler
and the Remote System Manager.
This book also contains information about changing
variables at installation time.
<P><HR><B>&#91; <A HREF="#Top_Of_Page">Top of Page</A> &#124; <A HREF="icsur008.html">Previous Page</A> &#124; <A HREF="icsur010.html">Next Page</A> &#124; <A HREF="icsurmst.html#ToC">Table of Contents</A> &#93;</B>
<A NAME=Bot_Of_Page>&nbsp;</A>
</BODY></HTML>


<HR>
<H1><A NAME="HDRGLO" HREF="icsur007.html#PToC_74">Appendix C. Glossary</A></H1>
<P>
This glossary defines terms used by the Internet Connection Secure Server.
<DL>
<P><DT>accessory script
<DD>A CGI script program that processes SEARCH, POST, PUT, or DELETE
requests.
The accessory scripts process requests that are not explicitly
mapped to a CGI script program named on an EXEC directive.
<P><DT>address
<DD>The unique code assigned to each device or
workstation connected to a network.
A standard Internet address (or IP address) is a 32-bit address field.
This field contains two parts.
The first part is the network address;
the second part is the host number.
See also <I>IP address</I>.
<P><DT>agent
<DD>
In systems management, a user that, for a particular interaction,
has assumed an agent role.
<DD>
An entity that represents one or more managed objects by
(a) emitting notifications regarding the objects and
(b) handling requests from managers for management operations
to modify or query the objects.
<P><DT>alias
<DD>A name assigned to a server.
The alias makes the server independent of the name of its host machine.
The alias must be defined in the domain name server.
<P><DT>asymmetric keys
<DD>In secure communications, the two keys in a key pair.
The keys are called asymmetric because one key holds more of the
encryption pattern than the other does.
See <I>key pair</I>.
<P><DT>authentication
<DD>In secure communications, a means of verifying the identity
of a server or browser (client) with whom you wish to communicate.
A sender's authenticity is demonstrated
by the digital certificate issued to the sender.
See also <I>certificate</I>.
<P><DT>browser
<DD>A client program that initiates requests to a server
and displays the returned information.
<P><DT>cache
<DD>A special-purpose buffer storage, smaller and faster than main
storage, used to hold a copy of data that may be frequently accessed.
Use of a cache reduces access time,
but may increase memory requirements.
<P><DT>caching proxy server
<DD>A proxy server that can store the documents it retrieves
from other servers in a local cache.
The server can then respond to subsequent requests for the
same documents without having to retrieve them from other servers.
This can improve response time.
<P><DT>CERN
<DD>Conseil Europeen pour la Recherche Nucleaire (European Laboratory
for Particle Physics).
Located in Geneva, CERN initiated the World Wide Web,
and was the first to create a Web server.
The CERN Web server is the basis for many commercially
available servers, such as IBM's Internet Connection Secure Server.
<P><DT>certificate
<DD>In secure communications, a digital document that binds
an encryption key to the identity of the certificate owner,
so that the certificate owner can be authenticated.
A certificate is issued by a certification authority (CA).
See also <I>encryption</I>, <I>certificate</I>, and
<I>certification authority (CA)</I>.
<P><DT>certification authority (CA)
<DD>In secure communications,
a trusted third party (such as VeriSign, Inc.)
or a designated internal authority who issues certificates.
See also <I>certificate</I>.
<P><DT>CGI (common gateway interface)
<DD>A standard interface between Web servers and external programs.
CGI scripts are programs that use this interface to perform tasks
not usually done by the server, such as form processing.
<P><DT>CGI program
<DD>A program that uses the common gateway interface (CGI)
to perform tasks not usually done by the server, such as form processing.
CGI programs can be written in any language supported by the operating
system on which the server is run.
The language can be a scripting language or a programming language.
<P><DT>client
<DD>A computer system or process that requests a service of
another computer system or process.
For example, a workstation or personal computer
requesting HTML documents from an IBM Internet Connection Secure Server
is a client of the IBM Internet Connection Secure Server it connects to.
<P><DT>configuration file
<DD>A file that describes the devices, optional features, communications
parameters, and programs installed on a workstation.
For Internet Connection Secure Server, the configuration file is named httpd.cnf
and by default is put in the path specified
on the SET ETC statement in your CONFIG.SYS file.
The configuration file contains directives
that define the various settings for the server.
<P><DT>cookie
<DD>A general mechanism that server-side connections, such as
CGI scripts, can use to store information on the
client side of the connection for later retrieval.
For example, a retail Web site can
store per-user preferences on the client, and have the client supply
those preferences every time that site is connected to.  A cookie
is introduced to the client in a Set-Cookie header, which is included
as part of an HTTP response.
<P><DT>default
<DD>A value, attribute, or option that is assumed
when none is explicitly specified.
<P><DT>directive
<DD>A statement used in the Internet Connection Secure Server configuration file
to define a particular setting for the server.
<P><DT>directory
<DD>A named grouping of files in a file system.
<P><DT>Distinguished Name
<DD>In secure communications, the name and address of the person
and organization to whom a certificate has been issued.
See also <I>certificate</I>.
<P><DT>document root directory
<DD>The primary directory where a Web server stores accessible documents.
When the server receives requests that do not point to a specific
directory, it tries to serve the request from this directory.
<P><DT>domain
<DD>In an internet, a part of the naming hierarchy.
A domain name consists of a sequence
of names (labels) separated by periods (dots).
<P><DT>domain name
<DD>A name of a host system in a network.
A domain name consists of a sequence
of names (labels) separated by periods (dots).
<P><DT>domain name server
<DD>A server program that supplies address-to-name
translation by mapping Internet addresses to domain names.
Use of a domain name server allows users
to request services of another computer using a symbolic name,
which is easier to remember than an Internet address.
<P><DT>dotted-decimal notation
<DD>The syntactical representation for a 32-bit integer that consists of
four 8-bit numbers, written in base 10 and separated by periods (dots).
It is used to represent IP addresses.
<P><DT>dynamic link library (DLL)
<DD>A file containing executable code and data bound to a program
at load time or run time.  The code and data in a dynamic link
library can be shared by several applications simultaneously.
<P><DT>encryption
<DD>In secure communications, a means of scrambling data
to prevent the data from being read by
anyone other than the intended recipient.
The sender uses a key to encrypt the message;
the recipient uses the decryption key.
See also <I>key</I> and <I>key pair</I>.
<P><DT>file extension
<DD>The last part of a file&#39;s name, following the period (dot).
For example, in the filename welcome.html, the file extension is html.
<P><DT>firewall
<DD>A computer that connects a private network, such as a business,
to a public network, such as the Internet.
It contains programs that limit the access between two networks.
See also <I>proxy gateway</I>.
<P><DT>FTP (File Transfer Protocol)
<DD>An application protocol used for transferring files to
and from host computers.
FTP requires a user ID, and a password to allow
access to files on a remote host system.
<P><DT>gateway
<DD>A functional unit that connects a local data network with
another network.
See also <I>proxy gateway</I>.
<P><DT>Gopher
<DD>The protocol, developed at the University of Minnesota,
that provides a menu-driven interface for accessing files
and information on other computers.
<P><DT>home page
<DD>The welcome page on the document root directory of a Web server.
Commonly used as the entry point for the contents of the server.
See also <I>welcome page</I>.
<P><DT>host
<DD>A computer, connected to a network, which provides
an access point to that network.
A host can be a client, a server, or a client and server
simultaneously.
<P><DT>host name
<DD>A name, such as tcpipidd.raleigh.ibm.com, that is defined
for an IP address, such as 9.67.97.103.
<P><DT>HTML (Hypertext Markup Language)
<DD>A language used to create hypertext documents.
Hypertext documents can include links to other related documents.
HTML controls the format of text and position of form input areas,
for example, as well as the navigable links.
<P><DT>HTML document
<DD>A document written in HTML that may contain links to other documents
that contain additional information about related terms or subjects.
<P><DT>HTTP (Hypertext Transfer Protocol)
<DD>The protocol used to transfer and display hypertext documents.
<P><DT>HTTP method
<DD>An action used by the Hypertext Transfer Protocol.
For example, HTTP methods include GET, POST, and PUT.
<P><DT>icon
<DD>A graphical representation of an object (a file or program),
consisting of an image, image background, and a label.
<P><DT>Internet
<DD>A wide area network connecting thousands of disparate networks
in industry, education, government, and research.
The Internet network uses TCP/IP as the standard
for transmitting information.
<P><DT>IP address
<DD>The unique 32-bit address that specifies the actual location
of each device or workstation in the Internet.
For example, 9.67.97.103 is an IP address.
<P><DT>key
<DD>In secure communications,
an algorithmic pattern used by a sender to encrypt messages,
and by a recipient to decrypt messages.
See also <I>encryption</I>, <I>key pair</I>, and
<I>key ring</I>.
<P><DT>key pair
<DD>In secure communications, a public key and a private key.
The sender uses the private key to encrypt the message;
the recipient uses the public key to decrypt the message.
Because the private key holds more of the encryption pattern
than the public key does, the key pair is called asymmetric.
See also <I>public key</I> and <I>private key</I>.
<P><DT>key ring
<DD>In secure communications, a file that contains public keys,
private keys, trusted roots, and certificates.
See also <I>public key</I>, <I>private key</I>,
<I>trusted root</I>, and <I>certificate</I>.
<P><DT>managed node
<DD>
In Internet communications, a workstation, server, or router
that contains a network management agent.
In the Internet Protocol (IP), the managed node usually contains a
Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP) agent.
<P><DT>method
<DD>An action used by the Hypertext Transfer Protocol.
For example, HTTP methods include GET, POST, and PUT.
<P><DT>MIB
<DD>
Management Information Base.
A collection of objects that can be accessed by means of
a network management protocol.
<DD>
A definition for management information that specifies
the information available from a host or gateway
and the operations allowed.
<P><DT>MIME (Multipurpose Internet Mail Extensions)
<DD>An Internet standard for multimedia e-mail,
including graphics, audio, and fax.
<P><DT>name server
<DD>A host that provides name resolution for a network.
Name servers translate symbolic names assigned to networks
and hosts into the Internet (IP) addresses used by machines.
<P><DT>network management station
<DD>
In the Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP),
a station that executes management application programs
that monitor and control network elements.
<P><DT>password
<DD>In secure communications, a string of characters that you use
to protect access to your key ring.
See also <I>key ring</I>.
<P><DT>path
<DD>A statement that indicates where a file is stored
on a particular drive.
The path consists of all the directories
that must be opened to get to a particular file.
The directory names are separated by the backslash (\).
<P><DT>persistent connection
<DD>A TCP/IP connection that allows the server to accept multiple
requests and to sent responses over the same connection.
<P><DT>PICS
<DD>Platform for Internet Content Selection.
An evolving set of specifications governing the creation and
use of ratings for Web information, including HTML files, as well
as image, sound, and animation files.  Content providers can rate
and label their own Web information; also, independent rating
services can rate Web information.  Internet users can then request
the ratings as a way to preview and filter Web information for
acceptable content.
<P><DT>port
<DD>An end point for communication between applications,
generally referring to a logical connection.
A port provides queues for sending and receiving data.
Each port has a port number for identification.
When the port number is combined with an Internet address,
it is called a socket address.
<P><DT>private key
<DD>In secure communications, an algorithmic pattern used
to encrypt messages that can be decrypted only
by the corresponding public key.
A private key is also used to decrypt messages
that were encrypted by the corresponding public key.
You keep your private key on your own system in a key
ring, protected by a password.
See also <I>encryption</I>, <I>public key</I>,
and <I>key ring</I>.
<P><DT>protection setup
<DD>A group of protection subdirectives that work together
to define how the server should control access to
the resources being protected.
You can define protection setups within the configuration file,
in separate protection setup files, or by using the
Configuration and Administration forms.
<P><DT>protocol
<DD>The set of rules governing the operation of functional units of a
communication system if communication is to take place.
Protocols can determine low-level details of machine-to-machine
interfaces, such as the order in which bits from a byte are sent;
they can also determine high-level exchanges
between application programs, such as file transfer.
<P><DT>proxy gateway
<DD>A type of firewall that protects computers in a business network
from access by users outside that network.
See also <I>firewall</I>.
<P><DT>proxy server
<DD>A server that can retrieve documents from other servers for
its clients.
<P><DT>public key
<DD>In secure communications, an algorithmic pattern used
to decrypt messages that were encrypted
by the corresponding private key.
A public key is also used to encrypt messages
that can only be decrypted by the corresponding private key.
You broadcast your public key to everyone who will
need to exchange encrypted messages with you.
See also <I>encryption</I>, <I>private key</I>, and
<I>key ring</I>.
<P><DT>README file
<DD>A file containing information and instructions for using the
associated program or programs
<P><DT>request
<DD>The part of a URL that follows the protocol and server host name.
For example, in the URL http://www.server.com/rfoul/sched.html,
the request is: /rfoul/sched.html
<P><DT>server
<DD>A computer that provides shared services to other computers
over a network;
for example, a file server, a print server, or a mail server.
<P><DT>server root directory
<DD>The directory where the Internet Connection Secure Server program is installed.
By default, the server root directory is
C&#58;\WWW\BIN.
<P><DT>server-side includes (SSI)
<DD>A facility for including dynamic information in documents sent
to clients, such as current date, the file's last modification date,
and the size or last modification of other files.
<P><DT>SSL
<DD>Secure Sockets Layer.
SSL is a popular security scheme developed by Netscape Communications
Corp., along with RSA Data Security, Inc.
SSL allows the client to authenticate the server and all
data and requests to be encrypted.
The URL of a secure server protected by
SSL begins with https (rather than http).
See also <I>authentication</I>.
<P><DT>subdirectory
<DD>A directory contained within another directory in a file
system hierarchy.
<P><DT>thread
<DD>The smallest unit of operation performed within a process.
<P><DT>thread pool
<DD>The threads that are either being used or available to Internet Connection Secure Server.
<P><DT>trusted root
<DD>In secure communications, the public key and
associated Distinguished Name of a certification authority (CA).
See also <I>public key</I>, <I>Distinguished Name</I>, and
<I>certification authority (CA)</I>.
<P><DT>URL (Uniform Resource Locator)
<DD>The address convention that indicates the location of an item on
the World Wide Web.
It includes the protocol followed by the fully-qualified host name,
and the request.
The server typically maps the request
portion of the URL to a path and file name.
For example, http://www.ibm.com/index.html
<P><DT>virtual host
<DD>One of several host names that you can define for a single
IP address in the domain name server.  That IP address can then
serve multiple files, rather than requiring different IP addresses
for different files.
<P><DT>WAIS (Wide Area Information Service)
<DD>A network information system that enables
clients to search documents on the World Wide Web.
<P><DT>Web
<DD>The World Wide Web:  the network of HTTP
servers that contain programs and files,
such as hypertext documents that contain links to other
documents on HTTP servers.
<P><DT>Web server
<DD>A server on the World Wide Web.
See also <I>Web</I>.
<P><DT>welcome page
<DD>A document that is returned by a Web server in response to
a request that points to a directory but does not contain a file name.
Each accessible directory on the server can have a welcome page.
See also <I>home page</I>.
<P><DT>wildcard character
<DD>An asterisk (*) used in a template.
For the template to be matched, an asterisk can be replaced
by any character string or single character.
A question mark must be replaced by one single character.
</DL>
<P><HR><B>&#91; <A HREF="#Top_Of_Page">Top of Page</A> &#124; <A HREF="icsur010.html">Previous Page</A> &#124; <A HREF="icsur012.html">Next Page</A> &#124; <A HREF="icsurmst.html#ToC">Table of Contents</A> &#93;</B>

</BODY></HTML>

<HR>
<H1><A NAME="HDRBIB" HREF="icsur007.html#PToC_75">Appendix D. Bibliography</A></H1>
<P>This bibliography lists the
books related to the Internet Connection Secure Server Version 4.2.
<HR>
<H2><A NAME="Header_76" HREF="icsur007.html#PToC_76">For AIX</A></H2>
<UL>
<P><LI><CITE>Quick Beginnings</CITE>, GC31-8482
<P>Explains how to plan for, install, start your server using
the default configuration settings, and stop your server.
Also explains how to view online help and print online books.
<P><LI><CITE>Webmaster's Guide for AIX, HP-UX, and Solaris</CITE>, GC31-8487
<P>Explains how to change the default configuration settings to
meet your needs, either by using the built-in configuration utility
or by editing the configuration file.
Also explains how to control and track users' access to your server, how
to include dynamic information in the files your server returns to
users, and how to set up a secure
environment for your users to conduct business.
<P><LI><CITE>Web Programming Guide</CITE> (available in HTML format
from your server's Front Page or in PDF format from this URL:
http://www.ics.raleigh.ibm.com)
<P>Explains how to write external programs that interact with the
Internet Connection Secure Server, via either the Common Gateway Interface (CGI) or the
Internet Connection API (ICAPI).
For example, you can write a CGI program
to generate a dynamic response to user input, or you can write an
ICAPI program to customize the way errors are handled.
</UL>
<HR>
<H2><A NAME="Header_77" HREF="icsur007.html#PToC_77">For HP-UX</A></H2>
<UL>
<P><LI><CITE>Quick Beginnings</CITE>, GC31-8483
<P>Explains how to plan for, install, start your server using
the default configuration settings, and stop your server.
Also explains how to view online help and print online books.
<P><LI><CITE>Webmaster's Guide for AIX, HP-UX, and Solaris</CITE>, GC31-8487
<P>Explains how to change the default configuration settings to
meet your needs, either by using the built-in configuration utility
or by editing the configuration file.
Also explains how to control and track users' access to your server, how
to include dynamic information in the files your server returns to
users, and how to set up a secure
environment for your users to conduct business.
<P><LI><CITE>Web Programming Guide</CITE> (available in HTML format
from your server's Front Page or in PDF format from this URL:
http://www.ics.raleigh.ibm.com)
<P>Explains how to write external programs that interact with the
Internet Connection Secure Server, via either the Common Gateway Interface (CGI) or the
Internet Connection API (ICAPI).
For example, you can write a CGI program
to generate a dynamic response to user input, or you can write an
ICAPI program to customize the way errors are handled.
</UL>
<HR>
<H2><A NAME="Header_78" HREF="icsur007.html#PToC_78">For OS/2 Warp</A></H2>
<UL>
<P><LI><CITE>Quick Beginnings</CITE>, GC31-8481
<P>Explains how to plan for, install, start your server using
the default configuration settings, and stop your server.
Also explains how to view online help and print online books.
<P><LI><CITE>Webmaster's Guide</CITE>, GC31-8486
<P>Explains how to change the default configuration settings to
meet your needs, either by using the built-in configuration utility
or by editing the configuration file.
Also explains how to control and track users' access to your server, how
to include dynamic information in the files your server returns to
users, and how to set up a secure
environment for your users to conduct business.
<P><LI><CITE>Web Programming Guide</CITE> (available in HTML format
from your server's Front Page or in PDF format from this URL:
http://www.ics.raleigh.ibm.com)
<P>Explains how to write external programs that interact with the
Internet Connection Secure Server, via either the Common Gateway Interface (CGI) or the
Internet Connection API (ICAPI).
For example, you can write a CGI program
to generate a dynamic response to user input, or you can write an
ICAPI program to customize the way errors are handled.
<P><LI><CITE>SystemView for OS/2 Version 1.1 Up and Running!</CITE>, SH19-4184
<P>Explains the concepts of systems management
in a LAN workgroup environment.
Also explains how to install and configure SystemView for OS/2, and
includes user scenarios to show you how to get started with
day-to-day systems management and software distribution.
</UL>
<HR>

Internet Connection Secure Server, via either the Common Gateway Interface (CGI) or the
Internet Connection API (ICAPI).
For example, you can write a CGI program
to generate a dynamic response to user input, or you can write an

</UL>

<P><LI><CITE>Webmaster's Guide</CITE>, GC31-8488

Also explains how to control and track users' access to your server, how
to include dynamic information in the files your server returns to

http://www.ics.raleigh.ibm.com)

Internet Connection Secure Server, via either the Common Gateway Interface (CGI) or the
Internet Connection API (ICAPI).
For example, you can write a CGI program
to generate a dynamic response to user input, or you can write an
ICAPI program to customize the way errors are handled.
</UL>

<A NAME=Top_Of_Page>&nbsp;</A>
<P>
<H1><A NAME="Header_1" HREF="icswgmst.html#ToC_1">Welcome&#33;</A></H1>
<P>
This book describes both the IBM Internet Connection Server and the IBM Internet Connection Secure Server for OS/2 Warp.
<UL>
<P><LI>Part 1 gives a brief overview of the IBM software servers and
a more extensive overview of the Internet Connection Server and the Internet Connection Secure Server.
<P><LI>Part 2 provides planning and installing information for your server.
<P><LI>Part 3 provides information on using your server.
</UL>
<P><B>Note: </B>When we say "the server" in this book, we mean either the
Internet Connection Server or the Internet Connection Secure Server.
When we say "the secure server", we mean only the Internet Connection Secure Server.
<HR>
<H2><A NAME="HDRROADMAP" HREF="icswgmst.html#ToC_2">Information road map</A></H2>
<BR>
<P><B><A NAME="Table_1">Table 1. Information road map</A></B><BR>

+--------------------------------------+--------------------------------------+
</TT></PRE><P>
<HR>
<H2><A NAME="HDRNEW41" HREF="icswgmst.html#ToC_3">What's new in Version 4.1</A></H2>
<P>
Enhancements for this version include:
<DL>
<P><DT><B>Improved logging and reporting
</B><DD>You can control the access requests that your server logs.  You can
also create and view reports based on the information in your access
logs.  You can customize your reports or use any of the report
templates that are provided.
<P><DT><B>Support for user-written programs that interface with your server
</B><DD>You can write programs that communicate and interact with your
server, via either the Common Gateway Interface (CGI) or the
Internet Connection API (ICAPI).
For example, you can write a CGI program to generate a dynamic
response to user input, or you can write an ICAPI program to
customize the way errors are handled.
<P><DT><B>Support for server-side includes
</B><DD>You can insert dynamic (changing) information into HTML
documents and CGI programs that the server sends to clients.
For example, you can include the current date, the file size,
and the date of the last change to the file.
<P><DT><B>Customizable error messages
</B><DD>You can tailor the messages that your server returns to clients
when errors occur.
For example, you can modify a message to explain
how to fix a particular problem.
For internal networks, you might even include the name and number of
the contact person.
<P><DT><B>Support for multiple IP addresses
</B><DD>If you run your server on a machine with multiple
network addresses, you can configure it to serve different files
based on the IP address that a request comes in on.
For example, an Internet service provider can configure
a single server to supply multiple customers with Web sites with
differing welcome pages, mapping rules, and access control.
</DL>
<P>
<B>Configuration directives new in Version 4.1</B>:
<A NAME="SPTNEWDIRS"><I>(Ref #1.)</I></A>
<BR>
<PRE><TT>
                                                                               
  &nbsp;
            AccessLogArchive                  DataFilter Error                 
            AccessLogExcludeMethod            ErrorLogArchive ErrorLogExpire   
            AccessLogExcludeMimeType          ErrorLogSizeLimit ErrorPage Log  
            AccessLogExcludeReturnCode        LogToGUI LogToSyslog NameTrans   
            AccessLogExcludeURL               ObjectType PostExit PreExit      
            AccessLogExpire                   ServerInit ServerTerm Service    
            AccessLogSizeLimit                UseACLs UseMetaFiles             
            AccessReportDescription                                            
            AccessReportExcludeHostName                                        
            AccessReportExcludeMethod                                          
            AccessReportExcludeReturnCode                                      
            AccessReportExcludeURL                                             
            AccessReportIncludeHostName                                        
            AccessReportIncludeURL                                             
            AccessReportRoot                                                   
            AccessReportTemplate                                               
            AccessReportTopList                                                
            Authentication Authorization                                       
            BindSpecific                                                       
                                                                               
</TT></PRE><P>

<H1><A NAME="Header_4" HREF="icswgmst.html#ToC_4">Basic Configuration</A></H1>
<HR>
<H1><A NAME="HDRCNF" HREF="icswgmst.html#ToC_5">Changing the default configuration</A></H1>
Changing configurations
<P>
Your server is operational once you install it.
After you have the server installed and running, you will probably
want to change some parts of the
default configuration file to make the server meet your
own particular needs.
<P>
This chapter explains what you can change about your server&#39;s
configuration, as well as how to change these items, by using the
Configuration and Administration forms or by editing the
configuration file.
<P>
